SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter a Company of Mutinous Citizens, with Staues, Clubs, and other weapons

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1. Citizen.
SPEECH.LINE: Before we proceed any further, heare me ſpeake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: Speake, ſpeake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: You are all resolu’d rather to dy then to famish?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: Resolu’d, resolu’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: First you know, Caius Martius is chiefe enemy to the people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: We know't, we know't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: Let vs kill him, and wee'l haue Corne at our own price. Is't a Verdict?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: No more talking on't; Let it be done, away, away

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: One word, good Citizens.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: We are accounted poore Citizens, the Patri-cians good: what Authority ſurfets one, would releeue vs. If they would yeelde vs but the ſuperfluitie while it were wholsome, wee might gueſſe they releeued vs hu-manely: But they thinke we are too deere, the leanneſſe that afflicts vs, the obiect of our misery, is as an inuento-ry to particularize their abundance, our ſufferance is a gaine to them. Let vs reuenge this with our Pikes, ere we become Rakes. For the Gods know, I ſpeake this in hunger for Bread, not in thirst for Reuenge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: Would you proceede especially against Caius
Martius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: Against him first: He's a very dog to the Com-monalty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: Consider you what Seruices he ha's done for his
Country?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: Very well, and could bee content to giue him good report for't, but that hee payes himselfe with bee-ing proud.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, but ſpeak not maliciously.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſay vnto you, what he hath done Famouslie, he did it to that end: though ſoft conscienc’d men can be content to ſay it was for his Countrey, he did it to please his Mother, and to be partly proud, which he is, euen to the altitude of his vertue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: What he cannot helpe in his Nature, you ac-count a Vice in him: You must in no way ſay he is co-uetous.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: If I must not, I neede not be barren of Accusa-tions he hath faults (with ſurplus) to tyre in repetition. Showts within. What ſhowts are these? The other ſide a'th City is risen: why ſtay we prating heere? To th’ Capitoll.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: Soft, who comes heere?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: Worthy Menenius Agrippa, one that hath al-wayes lou’d the people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: He's one honeſt enough, wold al the rest wer ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: What work's my Countrimen in hand? Where go you with Bats and Clubs? The matter Speake I pray you. 2 Cit. Our busines is not vnknowne to th’ Senat, they haue had inkling this fortnight what we intend to do, w now wee'l ſhew em in deeds: they ſay poore Suters haue ſtrong breaths, they ſhal know we haue ſtrong arms too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Menen.
SPEECH.LINE: Why Masters, my good Friends, mine honeſt
Neighbours, will you vndo your ſelues?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: We cannot Sir, we are vndone already.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: I tell you Friends, mo’t charitable care Haue the Patricians of you for your wants. Your ſuffering in this dearth, you may as well Strike at the Heauen with your ſtaues, as lift them Against the Roman State, whose course will on The way it takes: cracking ten thousand Curbes Of more ſtrong linke aſſunder, then can euer Appeare in your impediment. For the Dearth, The Gods, not the Patricians make it, and Your knees to them (not armes) must helpe. Alacke, You are transported by Calamity Thether, where more attends you, and you ſlander The Helmes o'th State; who care for you like Fathers, When you curse them, as Enemies. 2 Cit. Care for vs? True indeed, they nere car’d for vs yet. Suffer vs to famish, and their Store-houses cramm’d with Graine: Make Edicts for Vsurie, to ſupport Vsu-rers; repeale daily any wholsome Act established against the rich, and prouide more piercing Statutes daily, to chaine vp and restraine the poore. If the Warres eate vs not vppe, they will; and there's all the loue they beare vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Menen.
SPEECH.LINE: Either you must
Confeſſe your ſelues wondrous Malicious,
Or be accus’d of Folly. I ſhall tell you
A pretty Tale, it may be you haue heard it,
But ſince it ſerues my purpose, I will venture
To ſcale't a little more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2 Citizen.
SPEECH.LINE: Well,
Ile heare it Sir: yet you must not thinke
To fobbe off our disgrace with a tale:
But and't please you deliuer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: There was a time, when all the bodies members
Rebell’d against the Belly; thus accus’d it:
That onely like a Gulfe it did remaine
I'th midd'st a th’ body, idle and vnactiue,
Still cubbording the Viand, neuer bearing
Like labour with the rest, where th’ other Instruments
Did ſee, and heare, deuise, instruct, walke, feele,
And mutually participate, did minister
Vnto the appetite; and affection common
Of the whole body, the Belly anſwer’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: Well ſir, what anſwer made the Belly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I ſhall tell you with a kinde of Smile,
Which ne're came from the Lungs, but euen thus:
For looke you I may make the belly Smile,
As well as ſpeake, it taintingly replyed
To'th’ discontented Members, the mutinous parts
That enuied his receite: euen ſo mo’t fitly,
As you maligne our Senators, for that
They are not ſuch as you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: Your Bellies anſwer: What
The Kingly crown’d head, the vigilant eye,
The Counsailor Heart, the Arme our Souldier,
Our Steed the Legge, the Tongue our Trumpeter,
With other Muniments and petty helpes
In this our Fabricke, if that they—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: What then? Fore me, this Fellow ſpeakes.
What then? What then?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: Should by the Cormorant belly be restrain’d,
Who is the ſinke a th’ body.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, what then?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: The former Agents, if they did complaine,
What could the Belly anſwer?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: I will tell you,
If you'l bestow a ſmall (of what you haue little)
Patience awhile; you'st heare the Bellies anſwer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: Y'are long about it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: Note me this good Friend;
Your mo’t graue Belly was deliberate,
Not rash like his Accusers, and thus answered.
True is it my Incorporate Friends (quoth he)
That I receiue the generall Food at first
Which you do liue vpon: and fit it is,
Because I am the Store-house, and the Shop
Of the whole Body. But, if you do remember,
I ſend it through the Riuers of your blood
Euen to the Court, the Heart, to th’ ſeate o'th’ Braine,
And through the Crankes and Offices of man,
The ſtrongest Nerues, and ſmall inferiour Veines
From me receiue that naturall competencie
Whereby they liue. And though that all at once
(You my good Friends, this ſayes the Belly) marke me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſir, well, well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: Though all at once, cannot
See what I do deliuer out to each,
Yet I can make my Awdit vp, that all
From me do backe receiue the Flowre of all,
And leaue me but the Bran. What ſay you too't?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: It was an anſwer, how apply you this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: The Senators of Rome, are this good Belly,
And you the mutinous Members: For examine
Their Counsailes, and their Cares; disgest things rightly,
Touching the Weale a'th Common, you ſhall finde
No publique benefit which you receiue
But it proceeds, or comes from them to you,
And no way from your ſelues. What do you thinke?
You, the great Tœ of this Aſſembly?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: I the great Tœ? Why the great Tœ?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: For that being one o'th lowest, basest, poorest
Of this mo’t wise Rebellion, thou goest formost:
Thou Rascall, that art worst in blood to run,
Lead'st first to win ſome vantage.
But make you ready your ſtiffe bats and clubs,
Rome, and her Rats, are at the point of battell,
The one ſide must haue baile.
Hayle, Noble Martius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Thanks. What's the matter you diſſentious rogues
That rubbing the poore Itch of your Opinion,
Make your ſelues Scabs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: We haue euer your good word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: He that will giue good words to thee, wil flatter
Beneath abhorring. What would you haue, you Curres,
That like nor Peace, nor Warre? The one affrights you,
The other makes you proud. He that trusts to you,
Where he ſhould finde you Lyons, findes you Hares:
Where Foxes, Geese you are: No ſurer, no,
Then is the coale of fire vpon the Ice,
Or Hailstone in the Sun. Your Vertue is,
To make him worthy, whose offence ſubdues him,
And curse that Iustice did it. Who deserues Greatnes,
Deserues your Hate: and your Affections are
A ſickmans Appetite; who desires mo’t that
Which would encrease his euill. He that depends
Vpon your fauours, ſwimmes with finnes of Leade,
And hewes downe Oakes, with rushes. Hang ye: trust ye?
With euery Minute you do change a Minde,
And call him Noble, that was now your Hate:
Him vilde, that was your Garland. What's the matter,
That in these ſeuerall places of the Citie,
You cry against the Noble Senate, who
(Vnder the Gods) keepe you in awe, which else
Would feede on one another? What's their ſeeking?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: For Corne at their owne rates, wherof they ſay
The Citie is well ſtor’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Hang 'em: They ſay?
They'l ſit by th’ fire, and presume to know
What's done i'th Capitoll: Who's like to rise,
Who thriues, & who declines: Side factions, & giue out
Coniecturall Marriages, making parties ſtrong,
And feebling ſuch as ſtand not in their liking,
Below their cobled Shoœs. They ſay ther's grain enough?
Would the Nobility lay aside their ruth,
And let me vse my Sword, I’de make a Quarrie
With thousands of these quarter’d ſlaues, as high
As I could picke my Lance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Menen.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay these are almost thoroughly perswaded:
For though abundantly they lacke discretion
Yet are they paſſing Cowardly. But I beseech you,
What ſayes the other Troope?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: They are diſſolu’d: Hang em;
They ſaid they were an hungry, ſigh’d forth Prouerbes
That Hunger-broke ſtone wals: that dogges must eate
That meate was made for mouths. That the gods ſent not
Corne for the Richmen onely: With these ſhreds
They vented their Complainings, which being anſwer’d
And a petition granted them, a ſtrange one,
To breake the heart of generosity,
And make bold power looke pale, they threw their caps
As they would hang them on the hornes a'th Moone,
Shooting their Emulation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Menen.
SPEECH.LINE: What is graunted them?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Fiue Tribunes to defend their vulgar wisdoms
Of their owne choice. One's Iunius Brutus,
Sicinius Velutus, and I know not. Sdeath,
The rabble ſhould haue first vnroo'st the City
Ere ſo preuayl’d with me; it will in time
Win vpon power, and throw forth greater Theames
For Insurrections arguing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Menen.
SPEECH.LINE: This is ſtrange.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Go get you home you Fragments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Where's Caius Martius?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere: what’s the matter!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: The newes is ſir, the Volcies are in Armes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: I am glad on't, then we ſhall ha meanes to vent
Our mustie ſuperfluity. See our best Elders.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Sicinius Velutus, Annius Brutus Cominius, Titus Lartius, with other Senatours

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Sen.
SPEECH.LINE: Martius ‘tis true, that you haue lately told vs,
The Volces are in Armes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: They haue a Leader,
Tullus Auffidius that will put you too't:
I ſinne in enuying his Nobility:
And were I any thing but what I am,
I would wish me onely he.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: You haue fought together?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Were halfe to halfe the world by th’ eares, & he vpon my partie, I’de reuolt to make Onely my warres with him. He is a Lion That I am proud to hunt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Sen.
SPEECH.LINE: Then worthy Martius,
Attend vpon Cominius to these Warres.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: It is your former promise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir it is,
And I am constant: Titus Lucius, thou
Shalt ſee me once more ſtrike at Tullus face.
What art thou ſtiffe? Stand'st out?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tit.
SPEECH.LINE: No Caius Martius,
Ile leane vpon one Crutch, and fight with tother,
Ere ſtay behinde this Busineſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh true-bred.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sen.
SPEECH.LINE: Your Company to'th’ Capitoll, where I know
Our greatest Friends attend vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tit.
SPEECH.LINE: Lead you on: Follow Cominius, we must followe you, right worthy your Priority.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: Noble Martius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sen.
SPEECH.LINE: Hence to your homes, be gone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay let them follow,
The Volces haue much Corne: take these Rats thither,
To gnaw their Garners. Worshipfull Mutiners,
Your valour puts well forth: Pray follow.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Citizens ſteale away. Manet Sicin. & Brutus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Was euer man ſo proud as is this Martius?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: He has no equall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: When we were chosen Tribunes for the people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Mark’d you his lip and eyes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, but his taunts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Being mou’d, he will not ſpare to gird the Gods.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Bemocke the modest Moone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: The present Warres deuoure him, he is growne
Too proud to be ſo valiant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Such a Nature, tickled with good ſucceſſe, dis-daines the ſhadow which he treads on at noone, but I do wonder, his insolence can brooke to be commanded vn-der Cominius?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Fame, at the which he aymes,
In whom already he's well grac’d, cannot
Better be held, nor more attain’d then by
A place below the first: for what miscarries
Shall be the Generals fault, though he performe
To th’ vtmost of a man, and giddy censure
Will then cry out of Martius: Oh, if he
Had borne the busineſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Besides, if things go well,
Opinion that ſo ſtickes on Martius, ſhall
Of his demerits rob Cominius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Come: halfe all Cominius Honors are to Martius
Though Martius earn’d them not: and all his faults
To Martius ſhall be Honors, though indeed
In ought he merit not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Let's hence, and heare
How the dispatch is made, and in what fashion
More then his ſingularity, he goes
Vpon this present Action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru
SPEECH.LINE: Let's along.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Tullus Auffidius with Senators of Coriolus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Sen.
SPEECH.LINE: So, your opinion is Auffidius,
That they of Rome are entred in our Counsailes,
And know how we proceede,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Auf.
SPEECH.LINE: Is it not yours?
What euer haue bin thought one in this State
That could be brought to bodily act, ere Rome
Had circumuention: ‘tis not foure dayes gone
Since I heard thence, these are the words, I thinke
I haue the Letter heere: yes, heere it is;
They haue prest a Power, but it is not knowne
Whether for East or West: the Dearth is great,
The people Mutinous: And it is rumour’d,
Cominius, Martius your old Enemy
(Who is of Rome worse hated then of you)
And Titus Lartius, a mo’t valiant Roman,
These three leade on this Preparation
Whether ‘tis bent: mo’t likely, ‘tis for you:
Consider of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Sen.
SPEECH.LINE: Our Armie's in the Field:
We neuer yet made doubt but Rome was ready
To anſwer vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Auf.
SPEECH.LINE: Nor did you thinke it folly,
To keepe your great pretences vayl’d, till when
They needs must ſhew themselues, which in the hatching
It ſeem’d appear’d to Rome. By the discouery,
We ſhalbe ſhortned in our ayme, which was
To take in many Townes, ere (almost) Rome
Should know we were a-foot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Sen.
SPEECH.LINE: Noble Auffidius,
Take your Commiſſion, hye you to your Bands,
Let vs alone to guard Corioles
If they ſet downe before's: for the remoue
Bring vp your Army: but (I thinke) you'l finde
Th'haue not prepar’d for vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Auf.
SPEECH.LINE: O doubt not that,
I ſpeake from Certainties. Nay more,
Some parcels of their Power are forth already,
And onely hitherward. I leaue your Honors.
If we, and Caius Martius chance to meete,
‘Tis ſworne betweene vs, we ſhall euer ſtrike
Till one can do no more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: The Gods aſſist you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Auf.
SPEECH.LINE: And keepe your Honors ſafe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Sen.
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Sen.
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Volumnia and Virgilia, mother and wife to Martius: They ſet them downe on two lowe ſtooles and ſowe

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volum.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you daughter ſing, or expreſſe your ſelfe in a more comfortable ſort: If my Sonne were my Hus-band, I ſhould freelier reioyce in that absence wherein he wonne Honor, then in the embracements of his Bed, where he would ſhew mo’t loue. When yet hee was but tender-bodied, and the onely Sonne of my womb; when youth with comelineſſe pluck’d all gaze his way; when for a day of Kings entreaties, a Mother ſhould not ſel him an houre from her beholding; I considering how Honour would become ſuch a person, that it was no better then Picture-like to hang by th’ wall, if renowne made it not ſtirre, was pleas’d to let him ſeeke danger, where he was like to finde fame: To a cruell Warre I ſent him, from whence he return’d, his browes bound with Oake. I tell thee Daughter, I ſprang not more in ioy at first hearing he was a Man-child, then now in first ſeeing he had pro-ued himselfe a man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Virg.
SPEECH.LINE: But had he died in the Busineſſe Madame, how then?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volum.
SPEECH.LINE: Then his good report ſhould haue beene my Sonne, I therein would haue found iſſue. Heare me pro-feſſe ſincerely, had I a dozen ſons each in my loue alike, and none leſſe deere then thine, and my good Martius, I had rather had eleuen dye Nobly for their Countrey, then one voluptuously ſurfet out of Action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, the lady Valeria is come to visit you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Virg.
SPEECH.LINE: Beseech you giue me leaue to retire my ſelfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volum.
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed you ſhall not:
Me thinkes, I heare hither your Husbands Drumme:
See him plucke Auffidius downe by th’ haire:
(As children from a Beare) the Volces ſhunning him:
Me thinkes I ſee him ſtampe thus, and call thus,
Come on you Cowards, you were got in feare
Though you were borne in Rome; his bloody brow
With his mail’d hand, then wiping, forth he goes
Like to a Haruest man, that task’d to mowe
Or all, or loose his hyre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Virg.
SPEECH.LINE: His bloody Brow? Oh Iupiter, no blood.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volum.
SPEECH.LINE: Away you Foole; it more becomes a man
Then gilt his Trophe. The brests of Hecuba
When ſhe did ſuckle Hector, look’d not louelier
Then Hectors forhead, when it ſpit forth blood
At Grecian ſword. Contenning, tell Valeria
We are fit to bid her welcome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vir.
SPEECH.LINE: Heauens bleſſe my Lord from fell Auffidius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vol.
SPEECH.LINE: Hee'l beat Auffidius head below his knee,
And treade vpon his necke.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Valeria with an Vsher, and a Gentlewoman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: My Ladies both good day to you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vol.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet Madam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vir.
SPEECH.LINE: I am glad to ſee your Ladyship.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: How do you both? You are manifest house-kee-pers. What are you ſowing heere? A fine ſpotte in good faith. How does your little Sonne?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vir.
SPEECH.LINE: I thanke your Lady-ship: Well good Madam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vol.
SPEECH.LINE: He had rather ſee the ſwords, and heare a Drum, then looke vpon his Schoolmaster.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: A my word the Fathers Sonne: Ile ſweare ‘tis a very pretty boy. A my troth, I look’d vpon him a Wens-day halfe an houre together: ha's ſuch a confirm’d coun-tenance. I ſaw him run after a gilded Butterfly, & when he caught it, he let it go againe, and after it againe, and o-uer and ouer he comes, and vp againe: catcht it again: or whether his fall enrag’d him, or how 'twas, hee did ſo ſet his teeth, and teare it. Oh, I warrant how he mammockt it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vol.
SPEECH.LINE: One on's Fathers moods.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed la, tis a Noble childe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Virg.
SPEECH.LINE: A Cracke Madam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, lay aside your ſtitchery, I must haue you play the idle Huswife with me this afternoone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Virg.
SPEECH.LINE: No (good Madam)
I will not out of doores.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Not out of doores?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volum.
SPEECH.LINE: She ſhall, ſhe ſhall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Virg.
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed no, by your patience; Ile not ouer the threshold, till my Lord returne from the Warres.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Fye, you confine your ſelfe mo’t vnreasonably:
Come, you must go visit the good Lady that lies in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Virg.
SPEECH.LINE: I will wish her ſpeedy ſtrength, and visite her with my prayers: but I cannot go thither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volum.
SPEECH.LINE: Why I pray you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vlug.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis not to ſaue labour, nor that I want loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: You would be another Penelope: yet they ſay, all the yearne ſhe ſpun in Vliſſes absence, did but fill Athica full of Mothes. Come, I would your Cambrick were ſen-sible as your finger, that you might leaue pricking it for pitie. Come you ſhall go with vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vir.
SPEECH.LINE: No good Madam, pardon me, indeed I will not foorth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: In truth la go with me, and Ile tell you excellent newes of your Husband.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Virg.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh good Madam, there can be none yet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Verily I do not iest with you: there came newes from him last night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vir.
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed Madam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: In earnest it's true; I heard a Senatour ſpeake it. Thus it is: the Volcies haue an Army forth, against who[m] Cominius the Generall is gone, with one part of our Ro-mane power. Your Lord, and Titus Lartius, are ſet down before their Citie Carioles, they nothing doubt preuai-ling, and to make it breefe Warres. This is true on mine Honor, and ſo I pray go with vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Virg.
SPEECH.LINE: Giue me excuse good Madame, I will obey you in euery thing heereafter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vol.
SPEECH.LINE: Let her alone Ladie, as ſhe is now:
She will but disease our better mirth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Valeria.
SPEECH.LINE: In troth I thinke ſhe would:
Fare you well then. Come good ſweet Ladie.
Prythee Virgilia turne thy ſolemneſſe out a doore,
And go along with vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Virgil.
SPEECH.LINE: No
At a word Madam; Indeed I must not,
I wish you much mirth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val
SPEECH.LINE: Well, then farewell.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Martius, Titus Lartius, with Drumme and Co-lours, with Captaines and Souldiers, as before the City Corialus: to them a Meſſenger

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martius.
SPEECH.LINE: Yonder comes Newes:
A Wager they haue met.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lar.
SPEECH.LINE: My horse to yours, no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Tis done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lart.
SPEECH.LINE: Agreed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Say, ha's our Generall met the Enemy?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: They lye in view, but haue not ſpoke as yet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lart.
SPEECH.LINE: So, the good Horse is mine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mart.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile buy him of you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lart.
SPEECH.LINE: No, Ile nor ſel, nor giue him: Lend you him I will
For halfe a hundred yeares: Summon the Towne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: How farre off lie these Armies?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Within this mile and halfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Then ſhall we heare their Larum, & they Ours. Now Mars, I prythee make vs quicke in worke, That we with ſmoaking ſwords may march from hence To helpe our fielded Friends. Come, blow thy blast. They Sound a Parley: Enter two Senators with others on the Walles of Corialus Tullus Auffidious, is he within your Walles?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Senat.
SPEECH.LINE: No, nor a man that feares you leſſe then he,
That's leſſer then a little:
Hearke, our Drummes
Are bringing forth our youth: Wee'l breake our Walles
Rather then they ſhall pound vs vp our Gates,
Which yet ſeeme ſhut, we haue but pin’d with Rushes,
They'le open of themselues. Harke you, farre off
There is Auffidious. List what worke he makes
Among'st your clouen Army.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mart.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh they are at it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lart.
SPEECH.LINE: Their noise be our instruction. Ladders hoa.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter the Army of the Volces.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: They feare vs not, but iſſue forth their Citie. Now put your Shields before your hearts, and fight With hearts more proofe then Shields. Aduance braue Titus, They do disdaine vs much beyond our Thoughts, which makes me ſweat with wrath. Come on my fellows He that retires, Ile take him for a Volce, And he ſhall feele mine edge.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Alarum, the Romans are beat back to their Trenches Enter Martius Cursing

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: All the contagion of the South, light on you, You Shames of Rome: you Heard of Byles and Plagues Plaister you o’re, that you may be abhorr’d Farther then ſeene, and one infect another Against the Winde a mile: you ſoules of Geese, That beare the ſhapes of men, how haue you run From Slaues, that Apes would beate; Pluto and Hell, All hurt behinde, backes red, and faces pale With flight and agued feare, mend and charge home, Or by the fires of heauen, Ile leaue the Fœ, And make my Warres on you: Looke too't: Come on, If you'l ſtand fast, wee'l beate them to their Wiues, As they vs to our Trenches followes. Another Alarum, and Martius followes them to gates, and is ſhut in So, now the gates are ope: now proue good Seconds, ‘Tis for the followers Fortune, widens them, Not for the flyers: Marke me, and do the like.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Sol.
SPEECH.LINE: Foole-hardineſſe, not I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Sol.
SPEECH.LINE: Nor I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Sol
SPEECH.LINE: See they haue ſhut him in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All
SPEECH.LINE: To th’ pot I warrant him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tit.
SPEECH.LINE: What is become of Martius?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: Slaine (Sir) doubtleſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Sol.
SPEECH.LINE: Following the Flyers at the very heeles,
With them he enters: who vpon the ſodaine
Clapt to their Gates, he is himselfe alone,
To anſwer all the City.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lar.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh Noble Fellow!
Who ſensibly out-dares his ſenceleſſe Sword,
And when it bowes, ſtand'st vp: Thou art left Martius,
A Carbuncle intire: as big as thou art
Weare not ſo rich a Iewell. Thou was't a Souldier
Euen to Calues wish, not fierce and terrible
Onely in ſtrokes, but with thy grim lookes, and
The Thunder-like percuſſion of thy ſounds
Thou mad'st thine enemies ſhake, as if the World
Were Feauorous, and did tremble.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Martius bleeding, aſſaulted by the Enemy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Sol.
SPEECH.LINE: Looke Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lar.
SPEECH.LINE: O ‘tis Martius.
Let's fetch him off, or make remaine alike.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: They fight, and all enter the City.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: This will I carry to Rome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: And I this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 3.Rom
SPEECH.LINE: A Murrain on't, I tooke this for Siluer.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Martius, and Titus with a Trumpet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: See heere these mouers, that do prize their hours
At a crack’d Drachme: Cushions, Leaden Spoones,
Irons of a Doit, Dublets that Hangmen would
Bury with those that wore them. These base ſlaues,
Ere yet the fight be done, packe vp, downe with them.
And harke, what noyse the Generall makes: To him
There is the man of my ſoules hate, Auffidious,
Piercing our Romanes: Then Valiant Titus take
Conuenient Numbers to make good the City,
Whil'st I with those that haue the ſpirit, wil haste
To helpe Cominius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lar.
SPEECH.LINE: Worthy Sir, thou bleed'st,
Thy exercise hath bin too violent,
For a ſecond course of Fight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, praise me not:
My worke hath yet not warm’d me. Fare you well:
The blood I drop, is rather Physicall
Then dangerous to me: To Auffidious thus, I will appear and fight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lar.
SPEECH.LINE: Now the faire Goddeſſe Fortune,
Fall deepe in loue with thee, and her great charmes
Misguide thy Opposers ſwords, Bold Gentleman:
Prosperity be thy Page.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Thy Friend no leſſe,
Then those ſhe placeth highest: So farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lar.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou worthiest Martius,
Go ſound thy Trumpet in the Market place,
Call thither all the Officers a'th’ Towne,
Where they ſhall know our minde. Away.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Cominius as it were in retire, with ſoldiers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: Breath you my friends, wel fought, we are come off,
Like Romans, neither foolish in our ſtands,
Nor Cowardly in retyre: Beleeue me Sirs,
We ſhall be charg’d againe. Whiles we haue ſtrooke
By Interims and conueying gusts, we haue heard
The Charges of our Friends. The Roman Gods,
Leade their ſucceſſes, as we wish our owne,
That both our powers, with ſmiling Fronts encountring,
May giue you thankfull Sacrifice. Thy Newes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: The Cittizens of Corioles haue yſſued,
And giuen to Lartius and to Martius Battaile:
I ſaw our party to their Trenches driuen,
And then I came away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: Though thou ſpeakest truth,
Me thinkes thou ſpeak'st not well. How long is't ſince?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: Aboue an houre, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis not a mile: briefely we heard their drummes.
How could'st thou in a mile confound an houre,
And bring thy Newes ſo late?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: Spies of the Volces
Held me in chace, that I was forc’d to wheele
Three or foure miles about, else had I ſir
Halfe an houre ſince brought my report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: Whose yonder,
That doe's appeare as he were Flead? O Gods,
He has the ſtampe of Martius, and I haue
Before time ſeene him thus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Come I too late?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: The Shepherd knowes not Thunder fro[m] a Taber,
More then I know the ſound of Martius Tongue
From euery meaner man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martius.
SPEECH.LINE: Come I too late?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: I, if you come not in the blood of others,
But mantled in your owne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mart.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh! let me clip ye
In Armes as ſound, as when I woo’d in heart;
As merry, as when our Nuptiall day was done,
And Tapers burnt to Bedward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: Flower of Warriors, how is't with Titus Lartius?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: As with a man busied about Decrees:
Condemning ſome to death, and ſome to exile,
Ransoming him, or pittying, threatning th’ other;
Holding Corioles in the name of Rome,
Euen like a fawning Grey-hound in the Leash,
To let him ſlip at will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: Where is that Slaue
Which told me they had beate you to your Trenches?
Where is he? Call him hither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Let him alone,
He did informe the truth: but for our Gentlemen,
The common file, (a plague-Tribunes for them)
The Mouse ne're ſhunn’d the Cat, as they did budge
From Rascals worse then they.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: But how preuail’d you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Will the time ſerue to tell, I do not thinke:
Where is the enemy? Are you Lords a'th Field?
If not, why cease you till you are ſo?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: Martius, we haue at disaduantage fought,
And did retyre to win our purpose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: How lies their Battell? Know you on w ſide
They haue plac’d their men of trust?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: As I gueſſe Martius,
Their Bands i'th Vaward are the Antients
Of their best trust: O're them Auffidious,
Their very heart of Hope.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: I do beseech you,
By all the Battailes wherein we haue fought,
By th’ Blood we haue ſhed together,
By th’ Vowes we haue made
To endure Friends, that you directly ſet me
Against Affidious, and his Antiats,
And that you not delay the present (but
Filling the aire with Swords aduanc’d) and Darts,
We proue this very houre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: Though I could wish,
You were conducted to a gentle Bath,
And Balmes applyed to you, yet dare I neuer
Deny your asking, take your choice of those
That best can ayde your action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Those are they
That mo’t are willing; if any ſuch be heere,
(As it were ſinne to doubt) that loue this painting
Wherein you ſee me ſmear’d, if any feare
Leſſen his person, then an ill report:
If any thinke, braue death out-weighes bad life,
And that his Countries deerer then himselfe,
Let him alone: Or ſo many ſo minded,
Waue thus to expreſſe his disposition,
And follow Martius.

LINE.STAGEDIR: They all ſhout and waue their ſwords, take him vp in their Armes, and cast vp their Caps

SPEECH.LINE: Oh me alone, make you a ſword of me:
If these ſhewes be not outward, which of you
But is foure Volces? None of you, but is
Able to beare against the great Auffidious
A Shield, as hard as his. A certaine number
(Though thankes to all) must I ſelect from all:
The rest ſhall beare the busineſſe in ſome other fight
(As cause will be obey’d:) please you to March,
And foure ſhall quickly draw out my Command,
Which men are best inclin’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: March on my Fellowes:
Make good this ostentation, and you ſhall
Diuide in all, with vs.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Titus Lartius, hauing ſet a guard vpon Carioles, going with Drum and Trumpet toward Cominius, and Caius Mar-tius, Enters with a Lieutenant, other Souldiours, and a Scout

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lar.
SPEECH.LINE: So, let the Ports be guarded; keepe your Duties
As I haue ſet them downe. If I do ſend, dispatch
Those Centuries to our ayd, the rest will ſerue
For a ſhort holding, if we loose the Field,
We cannot keepe the Towne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lieu.
SPEECH.LINE: Feare not our care Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lart.
SPEECH.LINE: Hence; and ſhut your gates vpon's:
Our Guider come, to th’ Roman Campe conduct vs.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Martius and Auffidius at ſeueral doores.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile fight with none but thee, for I do hate thee
Worse then a Promise-breaker.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Auffid.
SPEECH.LINE: We hate alike:
Not Affricke ownes a Serpent I abhorre
More then thy Fame and Enuy: Fix thy foot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Let the first Budger dye the others Slaue,
And the Gods doome him after.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Auf.
SPEECH.LINE: If I flye Martius, hollow me like a Hare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Within these three houres Tullus
Alone I fought in your Corioles walles,
And made what worke I pleas’d: ‘Tis not my blood,
Wherein thou ſeest me maskt, for thy Reuenge
Wrench vp thy power to th’ highest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Auf.
SPEECH.LINE: Wer't thou the Hector, That was the whip of your bragg’d Progeny, Thou ſhould'st not ſcape me heere. Heere they fight, and certaine Volces come in the ayde of Auffi. Martius fights til they be driuen in breathles Officious and not valiant, you haue ſham’d me In your condemned Seconds.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Flourish. Alarum. A Retreat is ſounded. Enter at one Doore Cominius, with the Romanes: At another Doore Martius, with his Arme in a Scarfe

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: If I ſhould tell thee o’re this thy dayes Worke,
Thou't not beleeue thy deeds: but Ile report it,
Where Senators ſhall mingle teares with ſmiles,
Where great Patricians ſhall attend, and ſhrug,
I'th’ end admire: where Ladies ſhall be frighted,
And gladly quak’d, heare more: where the dull Tribunes,
That with the fustie Plebeans, hate thine Honors,
Shall ſay against their hearts, We thanke the Gods
Our Rome hath ſuch a Souldier.
Yet cam'st thou to a Morsell of this Feast,
Hauing fully din’d before.

LINE.STAGEDIR: Enter Titus with his Power, from the Pursuit.

SPEECH.LINE: Titus Lartius.
Oh Generall:
Here is the Steed, wee the Caparison:
Hadst thou beheld—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martius.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray now, no more:
My Mother, who ha's a Charter to extoll her Bloud,
When ſhe do's prayse me, grieues me:
I haue done as you haue done, that’s what I can,
Induc’d as you haue beene, that’s for my Countrey:
He that ha's but effected his good will,
Hath ouerta'ne mine Act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſhall not be the Graue of your deseruing,
Rome must know the value of her owne:
'Twere a Concealement worse then a Theft,
No leſſe then a Traducement,
To hide your doings, and to ſilence that,
Which to the ſpire, and top of prayses vouch’d,
Would ſeeme but modest: therefore I beseech you,
In ſigne of what you are, not to reward
What you haue done, before our Armie heare me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martius.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue ſome Wounds vpon me, and they ſmart
To heare themselues remembred.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: Should they not:
Well might they fester 'gainst Ingratitude,
And tent themselues with death: of all the Horses,
Whereof we haue ta'ne good, and good ſtore of all,
The Treasure in this field atchieued, and Citie,
We render you the Tenth, to be ta'ne forth,
Before the common distribution,
At your onely choyse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martius.
SPEECH.LINE: I thanke you Generall: But cannot make my heart consent to take A Bribe, to pay my Sword: I doe refuse it, And ſtand vpon my common part with those, That haue beheld the doing.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: A long flourish. They all cry, Martius, Martius, cast vp their Caps and Launces: Cominius and Lartius ſtand bare

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: May these ſame Instruments, which you prophane,
Neuer ſound more: when Drums and Trumpets ſhall
I'th’ field proue flatterers, let Courts and Cities be
Made all of false-fac’d ſoothing:
When Steele growes ſoft, as the Parasites Silke,
Let him be made an Ouerture for th’ Warres:
No more I ſay, for that I haue not wash’d
My Nose that bled, or foyl’d ſome debile Wretch,
Which without note, here's many else haue done,
You ſhoot me forth in acclamations hyperbolicall,
As if I lou’d my little ſhould be dieted
In prayses, ſawc'st with Lyes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: Too modest are you:
More cruell to your good report, then gratefull
To vs, that giue you truly: by your patience,
If 'gainst your ſelfe you be incens’d, wee'le put you
(Like one that meanes his proper harme) in Manacles,
Then reason ſafely with you: Therefore be it knowne,
As to vs, to all the World, That Caius Martius
Weares this Warres Garland: in token of the which,
My Noble Steed, knowne to the Campe, I giue him,
With all his trim belonging; and from this time,
For what he did before Corioles, call him,
With all th’ applause and Clamor of the Hoast,
Marcus Caius Coriolanus. Beare th’ addition Nobly euer?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SPEECH.LINE: Marcus Caius Coriolanus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martius.
SPEECH.LINE: I will goe wash:
And when my Face is faire, you ſhall perceiue
Whether I blush or no: howbeit, I thanke you,
I meane to ſtride your Steed, and at all times
To vnder-crest your good Addition,
To th’ faireneſſe of my power.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: So, to our Tent:
Where ere we doe repose vs, we will write
To Rome of our ſucceſſe: you Titus Lartius
Must to Corioles backe, ſend vs to Rome
The best, with whom we may articulate,
For their owne good, and ours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lartius.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhall, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martius.
SPEECH.LINE: The Gods begin to mocke me:
I that now refus’d mo’t Princely gifts,
Am bound to begge of my Lord Generall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: Tak't, ‘tis yours: what is't?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martius.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſometime lay here in Corioles,
At a poore mans house: he vs’d me kindly,
He cry’d to me: I ſaw him Prisoner:
But then Auffidius was within my view,
And Wrath o’re-whelm’d my pittie: I request you
To giue my poore Host freedome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh well begg’d:
Were he the Butcher of my Sonne, he ſhould
Be free, as is the Winde: deliuer him, Titus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lartius.
SPEECH.LINE: Martius, his Name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martius.
SPEECH.LINE: By Iupiter forgot:
I am wearie, yea, my memorie is tyr’d:
Haue we no Wine here?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: Goe we to our Tent: The bloud vpon your Visage dryes, ‘tis time It ſhould be lookt too: come.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: A flourish. Cornets. Enter Tullus Auffidius bloudie, with two or three Souldiors

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Auffi.
SPEECH.LINE: The Towne is ta'ne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sould.
SPEECH.LINE: 'Twill be deliuer’d backe on good Condition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Auffid.
SPEECH.LINE: Condition?
I would I were a Roman, for I cannot,
Being a Volce, be that I am. Condition?
What good Condition can a Treatie finde
I'th’ part that is at mercy? fiue times, Martius,
I haue fought with thee; ſo often hast thou beat me:
And would'st doe ſo, I thinke, ſhould we encounter
As often as we eate. By th’ Elements,
If ere againe I meet him beard to beard,
He's mine, or I am his: Mine Emulation
Hath not that Honor in't it had: For where
I thought to crush him in an equall Force,
True Sword to Sword: Ile potche at him ſome way,
Or Wrath, or Craft may get him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sol.
SPEECH.LINE: He's the diuell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Auf.
SPEECH.LINE: Bolder, though not ſo ſubtle: my valors poison’d,
With onely ſuff'ring ſtaine by him: for him
Shall flye out of it ſelfe, nor ſleepe, nor ſanctuary,
Being naked, ſicke; nor Phane, nor Capitoll,
The Prayers of Priests, nor times of Sacrifice:
Embarquements all of Fury, ſhall lift vp
Their rotten Priuiledge, and Custome 'gainst
My hate to Martius. Where I finde him, were it
At home, vpon my Brothers Guard, euen there
Against the hospitable Canon, would I
Wash my fierce hand in's heart. Go you to th’ Citie,
Learne how ‘tis held, and what they are that must
Be Hostages for Rome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Soul.
SPEECH.LINE: Will not you go?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Auf.
SPEECH.LINE: I am attended at the Cyprus groue. I pray you
(‘Tis South the City Mils) bring me word thither
How the world goes: that to the pace of it
I may ſpurre on my iourney.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Soul.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhall ſir.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Menenius with the two Tribunes of the people, Sicinius & Brutus

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: The Agurer tels me, wee ſhall haue Newes to night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Good or bad?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: Not according to the prayer of the people, for they loue not Martius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Nature teaches Beasts to know their Friends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray you, who does the Wolfe loue?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: The Lambe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: I, to deuour him, as the hungry Plebeians would the Noble Martius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: He's a Lambe indeed, that baes like a Beare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: Hee's a Beare indeede, that liues like a Lambe. You two are old men, tell me one thing that I ſhall aske you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Both.
SPEECH.LINE: Well ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: In what enormity is Martius poore in, that you two haue not in abundance?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: He's poore in no one fault, but ſtor’d withall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Especially in Pride.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: And topping all others in boasting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: This is ſtrange now: Do you two know, how you are censured heere in the City, I mean of vs a'th’ right hand File, do you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Both.
SPEECH.LINE: Why? how are we censur’d?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: Because you talke of Pride now, will you not be angry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Both.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, well ſir, well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ‘tis no great matter: for a very little theefe of Occasion, will rob you of a great deale of Patience: Giue your dispositions the reines, and bee angry at your pleasures (at the least) if you take it as a pleasure to you, in being ſo: you blame Martius for being proud.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brut.
SPEECH.LINE: We do it not alone, ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: I know you can doe very little alone, for your helpes are many, or else your actions would growe won-drous ſingle: your abilities are to Infant-like, for dooing much alone. You talke of Pride: Oh, that you could turn your eyes toward the Napes of your neckes, and make but an Interiour ſuruey of your good ſelues. Oh that you could.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Both.
SPEECH.LINE: What then ſir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then you ſhould discouer a brace of vn-meriting, proud, violent, testie Magistrates (alias Fooles) as any in Rome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Menenius, you are knowne well enough too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: I am knowne to be a humorous Patritian, and one that loues a cup of hot Wine, with not a drop of alay-ing Tiber in't: Said, to be ſomething imperfect in fauou-ring the first complaint, hasty and Tinder-like vppon, to triuiall motion: One, that conuerses more with the But-tocke of the night, then with the forhead of the morning. What I think, I vtter, and ſpend my malice in my breath. Meeting two ſuch Weales men as you are (I cannot call you Licurguſſes,) if the drinke you giue me, touch my Pa-lat aduersly, I make a crooked face at it, I can ſay, your Worshippes haue deliuer’d the matter well, when I finde the Aſſe in compound, with the Maior part of your ſylla-bles. And though I must be content to beare with those, that ſay you are reuerend graue men, yet they lye deadly, that tell you haue good faces, if you ſee this in the Map of my Microcosme, followes it that I am knowne well e-nough too? What harme can your beesome Conspectui-ties gleane out of this Charracter, if I be knowne well e-nough too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Come ſir come, we know you well enough.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Menen.
SPEECH.LINE: You know neither mee, your ſelues, nor any thing: you are ambitious, for poore knaues cappes and legges: you weare out a good wholesome Forenoone, in hearing a cause betweene an Orendge wife, and a Forfet-seller, and then reiourne the Controuersie of three-pence to a ſecond day of Audience. When you are hearing a matter betweene party and party, if you chaunce to bee pinch’d with the Collike, you make faces like Mum-mers, ſet vp the bloodie Flagge against all Patience, and in roaring for a Chamber-pot, dismiſſe the Controuersie bleeding, the more intangled by your hearing: All the peace you make in their Cause, is calling both the parties Knaues. You are a payre of ſtrange ones.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come, you are well vnderstood to bee a perfecter gyber for the Table, then a neceſſary Bencher in the Capitoll.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: Our very Priests must become Mockers, if they ſhall encounter ſuch ridiculous Subiects as you are, when you ſpeake best vnto the purpose. It is not woorth the wagging of your Beards, and your Beards deserue not ſo honourable a graue, as to ſtuffe a Botchers Cushion, or to be intomb’d in an Aſſes Packe-saddle; yet you must bee ſaying, Martius is proud: who in a cheape estimation, is worth all your predeceſſors, ſince Deucalion, though per-aduenture ſome of the best of 'em were hereditarie hang-men. Godden to your Worships, more of your conuer-sation would infect my Braine, being the Heardsmen of the Beastly Plebeans. I will be bold to take my leaue of you. Bru. and Scic. Aside. Enter Volumnia, Virgilia, and Valeria. How now (my as faire as Noble) Ladyes, and the Moone were ſhee Earthly, no Nobler; whither doe you follow your Eyes ſo fast?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volum.
SPEECH.LINE: Honorable Menenius, my Boy Martius appro-ches: for the loue of Iuno let's goe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Menen.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha? Martius comming home?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volum.
SPEECH.LINE: I, worthy Menenius, and with mo’t prosperous approbation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Menen.
SPEECH.LINE: Take my Cappe Iupiter, and I thanke thee: hoo, Martius comming home?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Ladies.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, ‘tis true.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volum.
SPEECH.LINE: Looke, here's a Letter from him, the State hath another, his Wife another, and (I thinke) there's one at home for you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Menen.
SPEECH.LINE: I will make my very house reele to night:
A Letter for me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Virgil.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes certaine, there's a Letter for you, I ſaw't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Menen.
SPEECH.LINE: A Letter for me? it giues me an Estate of ſe-uen yeeres health; in which time, I will make a Lippe at the Physician: The mo’t ſoueraigne Prescription in Galen, is but Emperickqutique; and to this Preseruatiue, of no better report then a Horse-drench. Is he not wounded? he was wont to come home wounded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Virgil.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh no, no, no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volum.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh, he is wounded, I thanke the Gods for't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Menen.
SPEECH.LINE: So doe I too, if it be not too much: brings a
Victorie in his Pocket? the wounds become him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volum.
SPEECH.LINE: On's Browes: Menenius, hee comes the third time home with the Oaken Garland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Menen.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha's he disciplin’d Auffidius ſoundly?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volum.
SPEECH.LINE: Titus Lartius writes, they fought together, but
Auffidius got off.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Menen.
SPEECH.LINE: And 'twas time for him too, Ile warrant him that: and he had ſtay’d by him, I would not haue been ſo fiddious’d, for all the Chests in Carioles, and the Gold that’s in them. Is the Senate poſſest of this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volum.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Ladies let's goe. Yes, yes, yes: The Senate ha's Letters from the Generall, wherein hee giues my Sonne the whole Name of the Warre: he hath in this action out-done his former deeds doubly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Valer.
SPEECH.LINE: In troth, there's wondrous things ſpoke of him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Menen.
SPEECH.LINE: Wondrous: I, I warrant you, and not with-out his true purchasing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Virgil.
SPEECH.LINE: The Gods graunt them true.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volum.
SPEECH.LINE: True? pow waw.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: True? Ile be ſworne they are true: where is hee wounded, God ſaue your good Worships? Martius is comming home: hee ha's more cause to be prowd: where is he wounded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volum.
SPEECH.LINE: Ith' Shoulder, and ith' left Arme: there will be large Cicatrices to ſhew the People, when hee ſhall ſtand for his place: he receiued in the repulse of Tarquin ſeuen hurts ith' Body.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: One ith' Neck, and two ith' Thigh, there's nine that I know.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volum.
SPEECH.LINE: Hee had, before this last Expedition, twentie fiue Wounds vpon him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: Now it's twentie ſeuen; euery gash was an
Enemies Graue. Hearke, the Trumpets.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volum.
SPEECH.LINE: These are the Vshers of Martius: Before him, hee carryes Noyse; And behinde him, hee leaues Teares: Death, that darke Spirit, in's neruie Arme doth lye, Which being aduanc’d, declines, and then men dye.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: A Sennet. Trumpets ſound. Enter Cominius the Generall, and Titus Latius: be-tweene them Coriolanus, crown’d with an Oaken Garland, with Captaines and Soul-diers, and a Herauld

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herauld.
SPEECH.LINE: Know Rome, that all alone Martius did fight
Within Corioles Gates: where he hath wonne,
With Fame, a Name to Martius Caius:
These in honor followes Martius Caius Coriolanus.
Welcome to Rome, renowned Coriolanus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: Welcome to Rome, renowned Coriolanus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coriol.
SPEECH.LINE: No more of this, it does offend my heart: pray now no more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: Looke, Sir, your Mother.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coriol.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh! you haue, I know, petition’d all the Gods for my prosperitie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volum.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, my good Souldier, vp:
My gentle Martius, worthy Caius,
And by deed-atchieuing Honor newly nam’d,
What is it (Coriolanus) must I call thee?
But oh, thy Wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: My gracious ſilence, hayle:
Would'st thou haue laugh’d, had I come Coffin’d home,
That weep'st to ſee me triumph? Ah my deare,
Such eyes the Widowes in Carioles were,
And Mothers that lacke Sonnes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: Now the Gods Crowne thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: And liue you yet? Oh my ſweet Lady, pardon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volum.
SPEECH.LINE: I know not where to turne.
Oh welcome home: and welcome Generall,
And y'are welcome all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: A hundred thousand Welcomes:
I could weepe, and I could laugh,
I am light, and heauie; welcome:
A Curse begin at very root on's heart,
That is not glad to ſee thee.
You are three, that Rome ſhould dote on:
Yet by the faith of men, we haue
Some old Crab-trees here at home,
That will not be grafted to your Rallish.
Yet welcome Warriors:
Wee call a Nettle, but a Nettle;
And the faults of fooles, but folly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: Euer right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: Menenius, euer, euer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herauld.
SPEECH.LINE: Giue way there, and goe on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: Your Hand, and yours?
Ere in our owne house I doe ſhade my Head,
The good Patricians must be visited,
From whom I haue receiu’d not onely greetings,
But with them, change of Honors.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volum.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue liued,
To ſee inherited my very Wishes,
And the Buildings of my Fancie:
Onely there's one thing wanting,
Which (I doubt not) but our Rome
Will cast vpon thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: Know, good Mother,
I had rather be their ſeruant in my way,
Then ſway with them in theirs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com
SPEECH.LINE: On, to the Capitall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: All tongues ſpeake of him, and the bleared ſights
Are ſpectacled to ſee him. Your pratling Nurse
Into a rapture lets her Baby crie,
While ſhe chats him: the Kitchin Malkin pinnes
Her richest Lockram 'bout her reechie necke,
Clambring the Walls to eye him:
Stalls, Bulkes, Windowes, are ſmother’d vp,
Leades fill’d, and Ridges hors’d
With variable Complexions; all agreeing
In earnestneſſe to ſee him: ſeld-showne Flamins
Doe preſſe among the popular Throngs, and puffe
To winne a vulgar ſtation: our veyl’d Dames
Commit the Warre of White and Damaske
In their nicely gawded Cheekes, toth' wanton ſpoyle
Of Phœbus burning Kiſſes: ſuch a poother,
As if that whatsœuer God, who leades him,
Were ſlyly crept into his humane powers,
And gaue him gracefull posture.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scicin.
SPEECH.LINE: On the ſuddaine, I warrant him Consull.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brutus.
SPEECH.LINE: Then our Office may, during his power, goe ſleepe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scicin.
SPEECH.LINE: He cannot temp'rately transport his Honors,
From where he ſhould begin, and end, but will
Lose those he hath wonne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brutus.
SPEECH.LINE: In that there's comfort.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scici.
SPEECH.LINE: Doubt not,
The Commoners, for whom we ſtand, but they
Vpon their ancient mallice, will forget
With the least cause, these his new Honors,
Which that he will giue them, make I as little question,
As he is prowd to doo't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brutus.
SPEECH.LINE: I heard him ſweare,
Were he to ſtand for Consull, neuer would he
Appeare i'th’ Market place, nor on him put
The Naples Vesture of Humilitie,
Nor ſhewing (as the manner is) his Wounds
Toth' People, begge their ſtinking Breaths.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scicin.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brutus.
SPEECH.LINE: It was his word:
Oh he would miſſe it, rather then carry it,
But by the ſuite of the Gentry to him,
And the desire of the Nobles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scicin.
SPEECH.LINE: I wish no better, then haue him hold that pur-pose, and to put it in execution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brutus.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis mo’t like he will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scicin.
SPEECH.LINE: It ſhall be to him then, as our good wills; a ſure destruction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brutus.
SPEECH.LINE: So it must fall out
To him, or our Authorities, for an end.
We must ſuggest the People, in what hatred
He ſtill hath held them: that to's power he would
Haue made them Mules, ſilenc’d their Pleaders,
And dispropertied their Freedomes; holding them,
In humane Action, and Capacitie,
Of no more Soule, nor fitneſſe for the World,
Then Cammels in their Warre, who haue their Prouand
Onely for bearing Burthens, and ſore blowes
For ſinking vnder them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scicin.
SPEECH.LINE: This (as you ſay) ſuggested,
At ſome time, when his ſoaring Insolence
Shall teach the People, which time ſhall not want,
If he be put vpon't, and that’s as easie,
As to ſet Dogges on Sheepe, will be his fire
To kindle their dry Stubble: and their Blaze
Shall darken him for euer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brutus.
SPEECH.LINE: What's the matter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: You are ſent for to the Capitoll:
‘Tis thought, that Martius ſhall be Consull:
I haue ſeene the dumbe men throng to ſee him,
And the blind to heare him ſpeak: Matrons flong Gloues,
Ladies and Maids their Scarffes, and Handkerchers,
Vpon him as he paſſ’d: the Nobles bended
As to Ioues Statue, and the Commons made
A Shower, and Thunder, with their Caps, and Showts:
I neuer ſaw the like.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brutus.
SPEECH.LINE: Let's to the Capitoll,
And carry with vs Eares and Eyes for th’ time,
But Hearts for the euent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scicin
SPEECH.LINE: Haue with you.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter two Officers, to lay Cushions, as it were, in the Capitoll

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Off.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come, they are almost here: how many ſtand for Consulships?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Off.
SPEECH.LINE: Three, they ſay: but ‘tis thought of euery one,
Coriolanus will carry it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Off.
SPEECH.LINE: That's a braue fellow: but hee's vengeance prowd, and loues not the common people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Off.
SPEECH.LINE: 'Faith, there hath beene many great men that haue flatter’d the people, who ne're loued them; and there be many that they haue loued, they know not wherefore: ſo that if they loue they know not why, they hate vpon no better a ground. Therefore, for Coriolanus neyther to care whether they loue, or hate him, manifests the true knowledge he ha's in their disposition, and out of his No-ble carelesneſſe lets them plainely ſee't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Off.
SPEECH.LINE: If he did not care whether he had their loue, or no, hee waued indifferently, 'twixt doing them neyther good, nor harme: but hee ſeekes their hate with greater deuotion, then they can render it him; and leaues nothing vndone, that may fully discouer him their opposite. Now to ſeeme to affect the mallice and displeasure of the Peo-ple, is as bad, as that which he dislikes, to flatter them for their loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Off.
SPEECH.LINE: Hee hath deserued worthily of his Countrey, and his aſſent is not by ſuch easie degrees as those, who hauing beene ſupple and courteous to the People, Bon-netted, without any further deed, to haue them at all into their estimation, and report: but hee hath ſo planted his Honors in their Eyes, and his actions in their Hearts, that for their Tongues to be ſilent, and not confeſſe ſo much, were a kinde of ingratefull Iniurie: to report otherwise, were a Mallice, that giuing it ſelfe the Lye, would plucke reproofe and rebuke from euery Eare that heard it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Off.
SPEECH.LINE: No more of him, hee's a worthy man: make way, they are comming.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: A Sennet. Enter the Patricians, and the Tribunes of the People, Lictors before them: Coriolanus, Mene-nius, Cominius the Consul: Scicinius and Brutus take their places by themselues: Corio-lanus ſtands

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Menen.
SPEECH.LINE: Hauing determin’d of the Volces,
And to ſend for Titus Lartius: it remaines,
As the maine Point of this our after-meeting,
To gratifie his Noble ſeruice, that hath
Thus ſtood for his Countrey. Therefore please you,
Mo’t reuerend and graue Elders, to desire
The present Consull, and last Generall,
In our well-found Succeſſes, to report
A little of that worthy Worke, perform’d
By Martius Caius Coriolanus: whom
We met here, both to thanke, and to remember,
With Honors like himselfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Sen.
SPEECH.LINE: Speake, good Cominius:
Leaue nothing out for length, and make vs thinke
Rather our ſtates defectiue for requitall,
Then we to ſtretch it out. Masters a'th’ People,
We doe request your kindest eares: and after
Your louing motion toward the common Body,
To yeeld what paſſes here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scicin.
SPEECH.LINE: We are conuented vpon a pleasing Treatie, and haue hearts inclinable to honor and aduance the Theame of our Aſſembly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brutus.
SPEECH.LINE: Which the rather wee ſhall be blest to doe, if he remember a kinder value of the People, then he hath hereto priz’d them at.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Menen.
SPEECH.LINE: That's off, that’s off: I would you rather had been ſilent: Please you to heare Cominius ſpeake?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brutus.
SPEECH.LINE: Mo’t willingly: but yet my Caution was more pertinent then the rebuke you giue it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Menen.
SPEECH.LINE: He loues your People, but tye him not to be their Bed-fellow: Worthie Cominius ſpeake. Coriolanus rises, and offers to goe away. Nay, keepe your place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Senat.
SPEECH.LINE: Sit Coriolanus: neuer ſhame to heare
What you haue Nobly done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coriol.
SPEECH.LINE: Your Honors pardon:
I had rather haue my Wounds to heale againe,
Then heare ſay how I got them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brutus.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I hope my words dis-bench’d you not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coriol.
SPEECH.LINE: No Sir: yet oft,
When blowes haue made me ſtay, I fled from words.
You ſooth’d not, therefore hurt not: but your People,
I loue them as they weigh—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Menen.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray now ſit downe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: I had rather haue one ſcratch my Head i'th’ Sun,
When the Alarum were ſtrucke, then idly ſit
To heare my Nothings monster’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Menen.
SPEECH.LINE: Masters of the People,
Your multiplying Spawne, how can he flatter?
That's thousand to one good one, when you now ſee
He had rather venture all his Limbes for Honor,
Then on ones Eares to heare it. Proceed Cominius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhall lacke voyce: the deeds of Coriolanus
Should not be vtter’d feebly: it is held,
That Valour is the chiefest Vertue,
And mo’t dignifies the hauer: if it be,
The man I ſpeake of, cannot in the World
Be ſingly counter-poys’d. At ſixteene yeeres,
When Tarquin made a Head for Rome, he fought
Beyond the marke of others: our then Dictator,
Whom with all prayse I point at, ſaw him fight,
When with his Amazonian Shinne he droue
The brizled Lippes before him: he bestrid
An o’re-prest Roman, and i'th’ Consuls view
Slew three Opposers: Tarquins ſelfe he met,
And ſtrucke him on his Knee: in that dayes feates,
When he might act the Woman in the Scene,
He prou’d best man i'th’ field, and for his meed
Was Brow-bound with the Oake. His Pupill age
Man-entred thus, he waxed like a Sea,
And in the brunt of ſeuenteene Battailes ſince,
He lurcht all Swords of the Garland: for this last,
Before, and in Corioles, let me ſay
I cannot ſpeake him home: he ſtopt the flyers,
And by his rare example made the Coward
Turne terror into ſport: as Weeds before
A Veſſell vnder ſayle, ſo men obey’d,
And fell below his Stem: his Sword, Deaths ſtampe,
Where it did marke, it tooke from face to foot:
He was a thing of Blood, whose euery motion
Was tim’d with dying Cryes: alone he entred
The mortall Gate of th’ Citie, which he painted
With ſhunleſſe destinie: aydeleſſe came off,
And with a ſudden re-inforcement ſtrucke
Carioles like a Planet: now all's his,
When by and by the dinne of Warre gan pierce
His readie ſence: then ſtraight his doubled ſpirit
Requickned what in flesh was fatigate,
And to the Battaile came he, where he did
Runne reeking o’re the liues of men, as if 'twere
A perpetuall ſpoyle: and till we call’d
Both Field and Citie ours, he neuer ſtood
To ease his Brest with panting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Menen.
SPEECH.LINE: Worthy man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Senat.
SPEECH.LINE: He cannot but with measure fit the Honors which we deuise him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: Our ſpoyles he kickt at,
And look’d vpon things precious, as they were
The common Muck of the World: he couets leſſe
Then Miserie it ſelfe would giue, rewards his deeds
With doing them, and is content
To ſpend the time, to end it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Menen.
SPEECH.LINE: Hee's right Noble, let him be call’d for.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Senat.
SPEECH.LINE: Call Coriolanus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Off.
SPEECH.LINE: He doth appeare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Menen.
SPEECH.LINE: The Senate, Coriolanus, are well pleas’d to make thee Consull.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: I doe owe them ſtill my Life, and Seruices.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Menen.
SPEECH.LINE: It then remaines, that you doe ſpeake to the
People.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: I doe beseech you,
Let me o’re-leape that custome: for I cannot
Put on the Gowne, ſtand naked, and entreat them
For my Wounds ſake, to giue their ſufferage:
Please you that I may paſſe this doing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, the People must haue their Voyces,
Neyther will they bate one iot of Ceremonie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Menen.
SPEECH.LINE: Put them not too't:
Pray you goe fit you to the Custome,
And take to you, as your Predeceſſors haue,
Your Honor with your forme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: It is a part that I ſhall blush in acting,
And might well be taken from the People.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brutus.
SPEECH.LINE: Marke you that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: To brag vnto them, thus I did, and thus
Shew them th’ vnaking Skarres, which I ſhould hide,
As if I had receiu’d them for the hyre
Of their breath onely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Menen.
SPEECH.LINE: Doe not ſtand vpon't:
We recommend to you Tribunes of the People
Our purpose to them, and to our Noble Consull
Wish we all Ioy, and Honor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Senat.
SPEECH.LINE: To Coriolanus come all ioy and Honor.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Flourish Cornets. Then Exeunt. Manet Sicinius and Brutus

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſee how he intends to vse the people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scicin.
SPEECH.LINE: May they perceiue's intent: he wil require them
As if he did contemne what he requested,
Should be in them to giue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, wee'l informe them
Of our proceedings heere on th’ Market place,
I know they do attend vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: Once if he do require our voyces, wee ought not to deny him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: We may Sir if we will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 3.Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: We haue power in our ſelues to do it, but it is a power that we haue no power to do: For, if hee ſhew vs his wounds, and tell vs his deeds, we are to put our ton-gues into those wounds, and ſpeake for them: So if he tel vs his Noble deeds, we must also tell him our Noble ac-ceptance of them. Ingratitude is monstrous, and for the multitude to be ingratefull, were to make a Monster of the multitude; of the which, we being members, ſhould bring our ſelues to be monstrous members.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: And to make vs no better thought of a little helpe will ſerue: for once we ſtood vp about the Corne, he himselfe ſtucke not to call vs the many-headed Multi-tude. _

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 3.Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: We haue beene call’d ſo of many, not that our heads are ſome browne, ſome blacke, ſome Abram, ſome bald; but that our wits are ſo diuersly Coulord; and true-ly I thinke, if all our wittes were to iſſue out of one Scull, they would flye East, West, North, South, and their con-sent of one direct way, ſhould be at once to all the points a'th Compaſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: Thinke you ſo? Which way do you iudge my wit would flye.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 3.Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay your wit will not ſo ſoone out as another mans will, ‘tis ſtrongly wadg’d vp in a blocke-head: but if it were at liberty, 'twould ſure Southward. 2 Cit. Why that way? 3 Cit. To loose it ſelfe in a Fogge, where being three parts melted away with rotten Dewes, the fourth would returne for Conscience ſake, to helpe to get thee a Wife. 2 Cit. You are neuer without your trickes, you may, you may. 3 Cit. Are you all resolu’d to giue your voyces? But that’s no matter, the greater part carries it, I ſay. If hee would incline to the people, there was neuer a worthier man. Enter Coriolanus in a gowne of Humility, with Menenius Heere he comes, and in the Gowne of humility, marke his behauiour: we are not to ſtay altogether, but to come by him where he ſtands, by ones, by twœs, & by threes. He's to make his requests by particulars, wherein euerie one of vs ha's a ſingle Honor, in giuing him our own voi-ces with our owne tongues, therefore follow me, and Ile direct you how you ſhall go by him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: Content, content.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh Sir, you are not right: haue you not knowne
The worthiest men haue done't?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: What must I ſay, I pray Sir?
Plague vpon't, I cannot bring
My tongue to ſuch a pace. Looke Sir, my wounds,
I got them in my Countries Seruice, when
Some certaine of your Brethren roar’d, and ranne
From th’ noise of our owne Drummes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Menen.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh me the Gods, you must not ſpeak of that,
You must desire them to thinke vpon you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coriol.
SPEECH.LINE: Thinke vpon me? Hang 'em,
I would they would forget me, like the Vertues
Which our Diuines lose by em.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: You'l marre all,
Ile leaue you: Pray you ſpeake to em, I pray you
In wholsome manner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Bid them wash their Faces,
And keepe their teeth cleane: So, heere comes a brace,
You know the cause (Sir) of my ſtanding heere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 3 Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: We do Sir, tell vs what hath brought you too't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Mine owne desert.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2 Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: Your owne desert.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: I, but mine owne desire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 3 Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: How not your owne desire?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: No Sir, 'twas neuer my desire yet to trouble the poore with begging.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 3 Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: You must thinke if we giue you any thing, we hope to gaine by you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Well then I pray, your price a'th’ Consulship.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1 Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: The price is, to aske it kindly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Kindly ſir, I pray let me ha't: I haue wounds to ſhew you, which ſhall bee yours in priuate: your good voice ſir, what ſay you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2 Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſhall ha't worthy Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: A match Sir, there's in all two worthie voyces begg’d: I haue your Almes, Adieu.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 3 Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: But this is ſomething odde.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2 Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: And 'twere to giue againe: but ‘tis no matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coriol.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray you now, if it may ſtand with the tune of your voices, that I may bee Consull, I haue heere the Customarie Gowne.
You haue deserued Nobly of your Countrey, and you haue not deserued Nobly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coriol.
SPEECH.LINE: Your Aenigma.
You haue bin a ſcourge to her enemies, you haue bin a Rod to her Friends, you haue not indeede loued the Common people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coriol.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſhould account mee the more Vertuous, that I haue not bin common in my Loue, I will ſir flatter my ſworne Brother the people to earne a deerer estima-tion of them, ‘tis a condition they account gentle: & ſince the wisedome of their choice, is rather to haue my Hat, then my Heart, I will practice the insinuating nod, and be off to them mo’t counterfetly, that is ſir, I will counter-fet the bewitchment of ſome popular man, and giue it bountifull to the desirers: Therefore beseech you, I may be Consull.
Wee hope to finde you our friend: and therefore giue you our voices heartily.
You haue receyued many wounds for your Coun-trey.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coriol.
SPEECH.LINE: I wil not Seale your knowledge with ſhewing them. I will make much of your voyces, and ſo trouble you no farther.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Both.
SPEECH.LINE: The Gods giue you ioy Sir heartily.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coriol.
SPEECH.LINE: Mo’t ſweet Voyces:
Better it is to dye, better to ſterue,
Then craue the higher, which first we do deserue.
Why in this Wooluish tongue ſhould I ſtand heere,
To begge of Hob and Dicke, that does appeere
Their needleſſe Vouches: Custome calls me too't.
What Custome wills in all things, ſhould we doo't?
The Dust on antique Time would lye vnswept,
And mountainous Error be too highly heapt,
For Truth to o’re-peere. Rather then foole it ſo,
Let the high Office and the Honor go
To one that would doe thus. I am halfe through,
The one part ſuffered, the other will I doe.
Here come moe Voyces.
Your Voyces? for your Voyces I haue ſought,
Watcht for your Voyces: for your Voyces, beare
Of Wounds, two dozen odde: Battailes thrice ſix
I haue ſeene, and heard of: for your Voyces,
Haue done many things, ſome leſſe, ſome more:
Your Voyces? Indeed I would be Consull.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: Hee ha's done Nobly, and cannot goe without any honeſt mans Voyce.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: Therefore let him be Consull: the Gods giue him ioy, and make him good friend to the People.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: Amen, Amen. God ſaue thee, Noble Consull.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Worthy Voyces.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Menenius, with Brutus and Scicinius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: You haue ſtood your Limitation:
And the Tribunes endue you with the Peoples Voyce,
Remaines, that in th’ Officiall Markes inuested,
You anon doe meet the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Is this done?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scicin.
SPEECH.LINE: The Custome of Request you haue discharg’d:
The People doe admit you, and are ſummon’d
To meet anon, vpon your approbation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Where? at the Senate-house?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scicin.
SPEECH.LINE: There, Coriolanus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: May I change these Garments?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scicin.
SPEECH.LINE: You may, Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cori.
SPEECH.LINE: That Ile ſtraight do: and knowing my ſelfe again,
Repayre toth' Senate-house.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile keepe you company. Will you along?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brut.
SPEECH.LINE: We ſtay here for the People.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scicin
SPEECH.LINE: Fare you well.
He ha's it now: and by his Lookes, me thinkes,
‘Tis warme at's heart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brut.
SPEECH.LINE: With a prowd heart he wore his humble Weeds:
Will you dismiſſe the People?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scici.
SPEECH.LINE: How now, my Masters, haue you chose this man?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: He ha's our Voyces, Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brut.
SPEECH.LINE: We pray the Gods, he may deserue your loues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: Amen, Sir: to my poore vnworthy notice,
He mock’d vs, when he begg’d our Voyces.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 3.Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: Certainely, he flowted vs downe-right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: No, ‘tis his kind of ſpeech, he did not mock vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: Not one amongst vs, ſaue your ſelfe, but ſayes
He vs’d vs ſcornefully: he ſhould haue ſhew’d vs
His Marks of Merit, Wounds receiu’d for's Countrey.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ſo he did, I am ſure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: No, no: no man ſaw 'em.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 3.Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: Hee ſaid hee had Wounds,
Which he could ſhew in priuate:
And with his Hat, thus wauing it in ſcorne,
I would be Consull, ſayes he: aged Custome,
But by your Voyces, will not ſo permit me.
Your Voyces therefore: when we graunted that,
Here was, I thanke you for your Voyces, thanke you
Your mo’t ſweet Voyces: now you haue left your Voyces,
I haue no further with you. Was not this mockerie?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Why eyther were you ignorant to ſee't?
Or ſeeing it, of ſuch Childish friendlineſſe,
To yeeld your Voyces?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brut.
SPEECH.LINE: Could you not haue told him,
As you were leſſon’d: When he had no Power,
But was a pettie ſeruant to the State,
He was your Enemie, euer ſpake against
Your Liberties, and the Charters that you beare
I'th’ Body of the Weale: and now arriuing
A place of Potencie, and ſway o'th’ State,
If he ſhould ſtill malignantly remaine
Fast Fœ toth' Plebeij, your Voyces might
Be Curses to your ſelues. You ſhould haue ſaid,
That as his worthy deeds did clayme no leſſe
Then what he ſtood for: ſo his gracious nature
Would thinke vpon you, for your Voyces,
And translate his Mallice towards you, into Loue,
Standing your friendly Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Thus to haue ſaid,
As you were fore-aduis’d, had toucht his Spirit,
And try’d his Inclination: from him pluckt
Eyther his gracious Promise, which you might
As cause had call’d you vp, haue held him to;
Or else it would haue gall’d his ſurly nature,
Which easily endures not Article,
Tying him to ought, ſo putting him to Rage,
You ſhould haue ta'ne th’ aduantage of his Choller,
And paſſ’d him vnelected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brut.
SPEECH.LINE: Did you perceiue,
He did ſollicite you in free Contempt,
When he did need your Loues: and doe you thinke,
That his Contempt ſhall not be brusing to you,
When he hath power to crush? Why, had your Bodyes
No Heart among you? Or had you Tongues, to cry
Against the Rectorship of Iudgement?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue you, ere now, deny’d the asker:
And now againe, of him that did not aske, but mock,
Bestow your ſu’d-for Tongues?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 3.Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: Hee's not confirm’d, we may deny him yet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: And will deny him:
Ile haue fiue hundred Voyces of that ſound.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: I twice fiue hundred, & their friends, to piece 'em.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brut.
SPEECH.LINE: Get you hence instantly, and tell those friends,
They haue chose a Consull, that will from them take
Their Liberties, make them of no more Voyce
Then Dogges, that are as often beat for barking,
As therefore kept to doe ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scici.
SPEECH.LINE: Let them aſſemble: and on a ſafer Iudgement,
All reuoke your ignorant election: Enforce his Pride,
And his old Hate vnto you: besides, forget not
With what Contempt he wore the humble Weed,
