How in his Suit he ſcorn’d you: but your Loues,
Thinking vpon his Seruices, tooke from you
Th’ apprehension of his present portance,
Which mo’t gibingly, vngrauely, he did fashion
After the inueterate Hate he beares you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brut.
SPEECH.LINE: Lay a fault on vs, your Tribunes,
That we labour’d (no impediment betweene)
But that you must cast your Election on him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scici.
SPEECH.LINE: Say you chose him, more after our commandment,
Then as guided by your owne true affections, and that
Your Minds pre-occupy’d with what you rather must do,
Then what you ſhould, made you against the graine
To Voyce him Consull. Lay the fault on vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brut.
SPEECH.LINE: I, ſpare vs not: Say, we read Lectures to you,
How youngly he began to ſerue his Countrey,
How long continued, and what ſtock he ſprings of,
The Noble House o'th’ Martians: from whence came
That Ancus Martius, Numaes Daughters Sonne:
Who after great Hostilius here was King,
Of the ſame House Publius and Quintus were,
That our best Water, brought by Conduits hither,
And Nobly nam’d, ſo twice being Censor,
Was his great Ancestor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scicin.
SPEECH.LINE: One thus descended,
That hath beside well in his person wrought,
To be ſet high in place, we did commend
To your remembrances: but you haue found,
Skaling his present bearing with his past,
That hee's your fixed enemie; and reuoke
Your ſuddaine approbation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brut.
SPEECH.LINE: Say you ne're had don't,
(Harpe on that ſtill) but by our putting on:
And presently, when you haue drawne your number,
Repaire toth' Capitoll.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: We will ſo: almost all repent in their election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brut.
SPEECH.LINE: Let them goe on:
This Mutinie were better put in hazard,
Then ſtay past doubt, for greater:
If, as his nature is, he fall in rage
With their refusall, both obserue and anſwer
The vantage of his anger.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Toth' Capitoll, come:
We will be there before the ſtreame o'th’ People:
And this ſhall ſeeme, as partly ‘tis, their owne,
Which we haue goaded on-ward.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Cornets. Enter Coriolanus, Menenius, all the Gentry, Cominius, Titus Latius, and other Senators

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Tullus Auffidius then had made new head.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Latius.
SPEECH.LINE: He had, my Lord, and that it was which caus’d
Our ſwifter Composition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: So then the Volces ſtand but as at first,
Readie when time ſhall prompt them, to make roade
Vpon's againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: They are worne (Lord Consull) ſo,
That we ſhall hardly in our ages ſee
Their Banners waue againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Saw you Auffidius?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Latius.
SPEECH.LINE: On ſafegard he came to me, and did curse
Against the Volces, for they had ſo vildly
Yeelded the Towne: he is retyred to Antium.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Spoke he of me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Latius.
SPEECH.LINE: He did, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: How? what?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Latius.
SPEECH.LINE: How often he had met you Sword to Sword:
That of all things vpon the Earth, he hated
Your person mo’t: That he would pawne his fortunes
To hopeleſſe restitution, ſo he might
Be call’d your Vanquisher.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: At Antium liues he?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Latius.
SPEECH.LINE: At Antium.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: I wish I had a cause to ſeeke him there,
To oppose his hatred fully. Welcome home.
Behold, these are the Tribunes of the People,
The Tongues o'th’ Common Mouth. I do despise them:
For they doe pranke them in Authoritie,
Against all Noble ſufferance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Paſſe no further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: Hah? what is that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brut.
SPEECH.LINE: It will be dangerous to goe on— No further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: What makes this change?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Menen.
SPEECH.LINE: The matter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: Hath he not paſſ’d the Noble, and the Common?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brut.
SPEECH.LINE: Cominius, no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue I had Childrens Voyces?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Senat.
SPEECH.LINE: Tribunes giue way, he ſhall toth' Market place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brut.
SPEECH.LINE: The People are incens’d against him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Stop, or all will fall in broyle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Are these your Heard?
Must these haue Voyces, that can yeeld them now,
And ſtraight disclaim their toungs? what are your Offices?
You being their Mouthes, why rule you not their Teeth?
Haue you not ſet them on?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: Be calme, be calme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: It is a purpos’d thing, and growes by Plot,
To curbe the will of the Nobilitie:
Suffer't, and liue with ſuch as cannot rule,
Nor euer will be ruled.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brut.
SPEECH.LINE: Call't not a Plot:
The People cry you mockt them: and of late,
When Corne was giuen them gratis, you repin’d,
Scandal’d the Suppliants: for the People, call’d them
Time-pleasers, flatterers, fœs to Nobleneſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Why this was knowne before.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brut.
SPEECH.LINE: Not to them all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue you inform’d them ſithence?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brut.
SPEECH.LINE: How? I informe them?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: You are like to doe ſuch busineſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brut.
SPEECH.LINE: Not vnlike each way to better yours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then ſhould I be Consull? by yond Clouds
Let me deserue ſo ill as you, and make me
Your fellow Tribune.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scicin.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſhew too much of that,
For which the People ſtirre: if you will paſſe
To where you are bound, you must enquire your way,
Which you are out of, with a gentler ſpirit,
Or neuer be ſo Noble as a Consull,
Nor yoake with him for Tribune.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: Let's be calme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: The People are abus’d: ſet on, this paltring
Becomes not Rome: nor ha's Coriolanus
Deseru’d this ſo dishonor’d Rub, layd falsely
I'th’ plaine Way of his Merit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Tell me of Corne: this was my ſpeech,
And I will ſpeak't againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: Not now, not now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Senat.
SPEECH.LINE: Not in this heat, Sir, now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Now as I liue, I will.
My Nobler friends, I craue their pardons:
For the mutable ranke-sented Meynie,
Let them regard me, as I doe not flatter,
And therein behold themselues: I ſay againe,
In ſoothing them, we nourish 'gainst our Senate
The Cockle of Rebellion, Insolence, Sedition,
Which we our ſelues haue plowed for, ſow’d, & ſcatter’d,
By mingling them with vs, the honor’d Number,
Who lack not Vertue, no, nor Power, but that
Which they haue giuen to Beggers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, no more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Senat.
SPEECH.LINE: No more words, we beseech you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: How? no more?
As for my Country, I haue ſhed my blood,
Not fearing outward force: So ſhall my Lungs
Coine words till their decay, against those Meazels
Which we disdaine ſhould Tetter vs, yet ſought
The very way to catch them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſpeake a'th’ people, as if you were a God,
To punish; Not a man, of their Infirmity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: 'Twere well we let the people know't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: What, what? His Choller?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: Choller? Were I as patient as the midnight ſleep,
By Ioue, 'twould be my minde.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: It is a minde that ſhall remain a poison
Where it is: not poyson any further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Shall remaine?
Heare you this Triton of the Minnoues? Marke you
His absolute Shall?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: 'Twas from the Cannon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: Shall? O God! but mo’t vnwise Patricians: why
You graue, but wreakleſſe Senators, haue you thus
Giuen Hidra heere to choose an Officer,
That with his peremptory Shall, being but
The horne, and noise o'th’ Monsters, wants not ſpirit
To ſay, hee'l turne your Current in a ditch,
And make your Channell his? If he haue power,
Then vale your Ignorance: If none, awake
Your dangerous Lenity: If you are Learn’d,
Be not as common Fooles; if you are not,
Let them haue Cushions by you. You are Plebeians,
If they be Senators: and they are no leſſe,
When both your voices blended, the great'st taste
Mo’t pallates theirs. They choose their Magistrate,
And ſuch a one as he, who puts his Shall,
His popular Shall, against a grauer Bench
Then euer frown’d in Greece. By Ioue himselfe,
It makes the Consuls base; and my Soule akes
To know, when two Authorities are vp,
Neither Supreame; How ſoone Confusion
May enter 'twixt the gap of Both, and take
The one by th’ other.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, on to'th’ Market place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Who euer gaue that Counsell, to giue forth
The Corne a'th’ Store-house gratis, as 'twas vs’d
Sometime in Greece.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, well, no more of that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: Thogh there the people had more absolute powre
I ſay they norisht disobedience: fed, the ruin of the State.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ſhall the people giue
One that ſpeakes thus, their voyce?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile giue my Reasons,
More worthier then their Voyces. They know the Corne
Was not our recompence, resting well aſſur’d
They ne're did ſeruice for't; being prest to'th’ Warre,
Euen when the Nauell of the State was touch’d,
They would not thred the Gates: This kinde of Seruice
Did not deserue Corne gratis. Being i'th’ Warre,
There Mutinies and Reuolts, wherein they ſhew’d
Mo’t Valour ſpoke not for them. Th’ Accusation
Which they haue often made against the Senate,
All cause vnborne, could neuer be the Natiue
Of our ſo franke Donation. Well, what then?
How ſhall this Bosome-multiplied, digest
The Senates Courtesie? Let deeds expreſſe
What's like to be their words, We did request it,
We are the greater pole, and in true feare
They gaue vs our demands. Thus we debase
The Nature of our Seats, and make the Rabble
Call our Cares, Feares; which will in time
Breake ope the Lockes a'th’ Senate, and bring in
The Crowes to pecke the Eagles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: Come enough.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Enough, with ouer measure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: No, take more.
What may be ſworne by, both Diuine and Humane,
Seale what I end withall. This double worship,
Whereon part do's disdaine with cause, the other
Insult without all reason: where Gentry, Title, wisedom
Cannot conclude, but by the yea and no
Of generall Ignorance, it must omit
Reall Neceſſities, and giue way the while
To vnstable Slightneſſe. Purpose ſo barr’d, it followes,
Nothing is done to purpose. Therefore beseech you,
You that will be leſſe fearefull, then discreet,
That loue the Fundamentall part of State
More then you doubt the change on't: That preferre
A Noble life, before a Long, and Wish,
To iumpe a Body with a dangerous Physicke,
That's ſure of death without it: at once plucke out
The Multitudinous Tongue, let them not licke
The ſweet which is their poyson. Your dishonor
Mangles true iudgement, and bereaues the State
Of that Integrity which ſhould becom't:
Not hauing the power to do the good it would
For th’ ill which doth controul't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Has ſaid enough.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha's ſpoken like a Traitor, and ſhall anſwer
As Traitors do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou wretch, despight ore-whelme thee:
What ſhould the people do with these bald Tribunes?
On whom depending, their obedience failes
To'th’ greater Bench, in a Rebellion:
When what’s not meet, but what must be, was Law,
Then were they chosen: in a better houre,
Let what is meet, be ſaide it must be meet,
And throw their power i'th’ dust.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Manifest Treason.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: This a Consull? No.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: The Ediles hœ: Let him be apprehended:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Go call the people, in whose name my Selfe
Attach thee as a Traitorous Innouator:
A Fœ to'th’ publike Weale. Obey I charge thee,
And follow to thine anſwer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Hence old Goat.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: Wee'l Surety him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: Ag’d ſir, hands off.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Hence rotten thing, or I ſhall ſhake thy bones
Out of thy Garments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Helpe ye Citizens.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter a rabble of Plebeians with the Aediles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: On both ſides more respect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere's hee, that would take from you all your power.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Seize him Aediles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: Downe with him, downe with him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2 Sen.
SPEECH.LINE: Weapons, weapons, weapons:
Tribunes, Patricians, Citizens: what ho:
Sicinius, Brutus, Coriolanus, Citizens.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace, peace, peace, ſtay, hold, peace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: What is about to be? I am out of Breath,
Confusions neere, I cannot ſpeake. You, Tribunes
To'th’ people: Coriolanus, patience: Speak good Sicinius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scici.
SPEECH.LINE: Heare me, People peace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: Let's here our Tribune: peace, ſpeake, ſpeake, ſpeake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scici.
SPEECH.LINE: You are at point to lose your Liberties:
Martius would haue all from you; Martius,
Whom late you haue nam’d for Consull.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: Fie, fie, fie, this is the way to kindle, not to quench.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sena.
SPEECH.LINE: To vnbuild the Citie, and to lay all flat.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scici.
SPEECH.LINE: What is the Citie, but the People?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: True, the People are the Citie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brut.
SPEECH.LINE: By the consent of all, we were establish’d the
Peoples Magistrates.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſo remaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: And ſo are like to doe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: That is the way to lay the Citie flat,
To bring the Roofe to the Foundation,
And burie all, which yet distinctly raunges
In heapes, and piles of Ruine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scici.
SPEECH.LINE: This deserues Death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brut.
SPEECH.LINE: Or let vs ſtand to our Authoritie,
Or let vs lose it: we doe here pronounce,
Vpon the part o'th’ People, in whose power
We were elected theirs, Martius is worthy
Of present Death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scici.
SPEECH.LINE: Therefore lay hold of him:
Beare him toth' Rock Tarpeian, and from thence
Into destruction cast him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brut.
SPEECH.LINE: Aediles ſeize him.
All Ple.
Yeeld Martius, yeeld.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: Heare me one word, 'beseech you Tribunes, heare me but a word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aediles.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace, peace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: Be that you ſeeme, truly your Countries friend,
And temp'rately proceed to what you would
Thus violently redreſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brut.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, those cold wayes,
That ſeeme like prudent helpes, are very poysonous,
Where the Disease is violent. Lay hands vpon him,
And beare him to the Rock.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: No, Ile die here:
There's ſome among you haue beheld me fighting,
Come trie vpon your ſelues, what you haue ſeene me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: Downe with that Sword, Tribunes withdraw a while.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brut.
SPEECH.LINE: Lay hands vpon him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: Helpe Martius, helpe: you that be noble, helpe him young and old.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All
SPEECH.LINE: Downe with him, downe with him.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: In this Mutinie, the Tribunes, the Aediles, and the People are beat in

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: Goe, get you to our House: be gone, away.
All will be naught else.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Sena.
SPEECH.LINE: Get you gone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: Stand fast, we haue as many friends as enemies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: Shall it be put to that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sena.
SPEECH.LINE: The Gods forbid:
I prythee noble friend, home to thy House,
Leaue vs to cure this Cause.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: For ‘tis a Sore vpon vs,
You cannot Tent your ſelfe: be gone, 'beseech you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Come Sir, along with vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: I would they were Barbarians, as they are,
Though in Rome litter’d: not Romans, as they are not,
Though calued i'th’ Porch o'th’ Capitoll:
Be gone, put not your worthy Rage into your Tongue,
One time will owe another.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: On faire ground, I could beat fortie of them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: I could my ſelfe take vp a Brace o'th’ best of them, yea, the two Tribunes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: But now ‘tis oddes beyond Arithmetick,
And Manhood is call’d Foolerie, when it ſtands
Against a falling Fabrick. Will you hence,
Before the Tagge returne? whose Rage doth rend
Like interrupted Waters, and o’re-beare
What they are vs’d to beare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray you be gone:
Ile trie whether my old Wit be in request
With those that haue but little: this must be patcht
With Cloth of any Colour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, come away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patri.
SPEECH.LINE: This man ha's marr’d his fortune.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: His nature is too noble for the World:
He would not flatter Neptune for his Trident,
Or Ioue, for's power to Thunder: his Heart's his Mouth:
What his Brest forges, that his Tongue must vent,
And being angry, does forget that euer
He heard the Name of Death.
Here's goodly worke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patri.
SPEECH.LINE: I would they were a bed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: I would they were in Tyber.
What the vengeance, could he not ſpeake 'em faire?

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Brutus and Sicinius with the rabble againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Where is this Viper,
That would depopulate the city, & be euery man himself

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: You worthy Tribunes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: He ſhall be throwne downe the Tarpeian rock
With rigorous hands: he hath resisted Law,
And therefore Law ſhall ſcorne him further Triall
Then the ſeuerity of the publike Power,
Which he ſo ſets at naught.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1 Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: He ſhall well know the Noble Tribunes are
The peoples mouths, and we their hands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: He ſhall ſure ont.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Me.
SPEECH.LINE: Do not cry hauocke, where you ſhold but hunt
With modest warrant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, how com'st that you haue holpe
To make this rescue?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere me ſpeake? As I do know
The Consuls worthineſſe, ſo can I name his Faults.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Consull? what Consull?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: The Consull Coriolanus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: He Consull.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: No, no, no, no, no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: If by the Tribunes leaue,
And yours good people,
I may be heard, I would craue a word or two,
The which ſhall turne you to no further harme,
Then ſo much loſſe of time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sic.
SPEECH.LINE: Speake breefely then,
For we are peremptory to dispatch
This Viporous Traitor: to eiect him hence
Were but one danger, and to keepe him heere
Our certaine death: therefore it is decreed,
He dyes to night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Menen.
SPEECH.LINE: Now the good Gods forbid,
That our renowned Rome, whose gratitude
Towards her deserued Children, is enroll’d
In Ioues owne Booke, like an vnnaturall Dam
Should now eate vp her owne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: He's a Disease that must be cut away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh he's a Limbe, that ha's but a Disease
Mortall, to cut it off: to cure it, easie.
What ha's he done to Rome, that’s worthy death?
Killing our Enemies, the blood he hath lost
(Which I dare vouch, is more then that he hath
By many an Ounce) he dropp’d it for his Country:
And what is left, to loose it by his Countrey,
Were to vs all that doo't, and ſuffer it
A brand to th’ end a'th World.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: This is cleane kamme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brut.
SPEECH.LINE: Meerely awry:
When he did loue his Country, it honour’d him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Menen.
SPEECH.LINE: The ſeruice of the foote
Being once gangren’d, is not then respected
For what before it was.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Wee'l heare no more:
Pursue him to his house, and plucke him thence,
Least his infection being of catching nature,
Spred further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Menen.
SPEECH.LINE: One word more, one word:
This Tiger-footed-rage, when it ſhall find
The harme of vnskan’d ſwiftneſſe, will (too late)
Tye Leaden pounds too's heeles. Proceed by Proceſſe,
Least parties (as he is belou’d) breake out,
And ſacke great Rome with Romanes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brut.
SPEECH.LINE: If it were ſo?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: What do ye talke?
Haue we not had a taste of his Obedience?
Our Ediles ſmot: our ſelues resisted: come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: Consider this: He ha's bin bred i'th’ Warres
Since a could draw a Sword, and is ill-school’d
In boulted Language: Meale and Bran together
He throwes without distinction. Giue me leaue,
Ile go to him, and vndertake to bring him in peace,
Where he ſhall anſwer by a lawfull Forme
(In peace) to his vtmost perill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Sen.
SPEECH.LINE: Noble Tribunes,
It is the humane way: the other course
Will proue to bloody: and the end of it,
Vnknowne to the Beginning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sic.
SPEECH.LINE: Noble Menenius, be you then as the peoples officer:
Masters, lay downe your Weapons.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Go not home.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sic.
SPEECH.LINE: Meet on the Market place: wee'l attend you there:
Where if you bring not Martius, wee'l proceede
In our first way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Menen.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile bring him to you.
Let me desire your company: he must come,
Or what is worst will follow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sena
SPEECH.LINE: Pray you let's to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Let them pull all about mine eares, present me
Death on the Wheele, or at wilde Horses heeles,
Or pile ten hilles on the Tarpeian Rocke,
That the precipitation might downe ſtretch
Below the beame of ſight; yet will I ſtill
Be thus to them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Noble.
SPEECH.LINE: You do the Nobler.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: I muse my Mother
Do's not approue me further, who was wont
To call them Wollen Vaſſailes, things created
To buy and ſell with Groats, to ſhew bare heads
In Congregations, to yawne, be ſtill, and wonder,
When one but of my ordinance ſtood vp
To ſpeake of Peace, or Warre. I talke of you,
Why did you wish me milder? Would you haue me
False to my Nature? Rather ſay, I play
The man I am.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volum.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh ſir, ſir, ſir,
I would haue had you put your power well on
Before you had worne it out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Let go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vol.
SPEECH.LINE: You might haue beene enough the man you are,
With ſtriuing leſſe to be ſo: Leſſer had bin
The things of your dispositions, if
You had not ſhew’d them how ye were dispos’d
Ere they lack’d power to croſſe you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Let them hang.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volum.
SPEECH.LINE: I, and burne too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come, you haue bin too rough, ſomthing too rough: you must returne, and mend it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sen.
SPEECH.LINE: There's no remedy,
Vnleſſe by not ſo doing, our good Citie
Cleaue in the midd'st, and perish.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volum.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray be counsail’d;
I haue a heart as little apt as yours,
But yet a braine, that leades my vse of Anger
To better vantage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: Well ſaid, Noble woman:
Before he ſhould thus ſtoope to'th’ heart, but that
The violent fit a'th’ time craues it as Physicke
For the whole State; I would put mine Armour on,
Which I can ſcarsely beare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: What must I do?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: Returne to th’ Tribunes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, what then? what then?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: Repent, what you haue ſpoke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: For them, I cannot do it to the Gods,
Must I then doo't to them?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volum.
SPEECH.LINE: You are too absolute,
Though therein you can neuer be too Noble,
But when extremities ſpeake. I haue heard you ſay,
Honor and Policy, like vnseuer’d Friends,
I'th’ Warre do grow together: Grant that, and tell me
In Peace, what each of them by th’ other loose,
That they combine not there?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Tuſh, tuſh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: A good demand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volum.
SPEECH.LINE: If it be Honor in your Warres, to ſeeme
The ſame you are not, which for your best ends
You adopt your policy: How is it leſſe or worse
That it ſhall hold Companionship in Peace
With Honour, as in Warre; ſince that to both
It ſtands in like request.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Why force you this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volum.
SPEECH.LINE: Because, that
Now it lyes you on to ſpeake to th’ people:
Not by your owne instruction, nor by'th’ matter
Which your heart prompts you, but with ſuch words
That are but roated in your Tongue;
Though but Bastards, and Syllables
Of no allowance, to your bosomes truth.
Now, this no more dishonors you at all,
Then to take in a Towne with gentle words,
Which else would put you to your fortune, and
The hazard of much blood.
I would diſſemble with my Nature, where
My Fortunes and my Friends at ſtake, requir’d
I ſhould do ſo in Honor. I am in this
Your Wife, your Sonne: These Senators, the Nobles,
And you, will rather ſhew our generall Lowts,
How you can frowne, then ſpend a fawne vpon 'em,
For the inheritance of their loues, and ſafegard
Of what that want might ruine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Menen.
SPEECH.LINE: Noble Lady,
Come goe with vs, ſpeake faire: you may ſalue ſo,
Not what is dangerous present, but the loſſe
Of what is past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volum.
SPEECH.LINE: I prythee now, my Sonne,
Goe to them, with this Bonnet in thy hand,
And thus farre hauing ſtretcht it (here be with them)
Thy Knee buſſing the ſtones: for in ſuch busineſſe
Action is eloquence, and the eyes of th’ ignorant
More learned then the eares, wauing thy head,
Which often thus correcting thy ſtout heart,
Now humble as the ripest Mulberry,
That will not hold the handling: or ſay to them,
Thou art their Souldier, and being bred in broyles,
Hast not the ſoft way, which thou do'st confeſſe
Were fit for thee to vse, as they to clayme,
In asking their good loues, but thou wilt frame
Thy ſelfe (forsooth) hereafter theirs ſo farre,
As thou hast power and person.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Menen.
SPEECH.LINE: This but done,
Euen as ſhe ſpeakes, why their hearts were yours:
For they haue Pardons, being ask’d, as free,
As words to little purpose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volum.
SPEECH.LINE: Prythee now,
Goe, and be rul’d: although I know thou hadst rather
Follow thine Enemie in a fierie Gulfe,
Then flatter him in a Bower.
Here is Cominius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue beene i'th’ Market place: and Sir ‘tis fit
You make ſtrong partie, or defend your ſelfe
By calmeneſſe, or by absence: all's in anger.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Menen.
SPEECH.LINE: Onely faire ſpeech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke 'twill ſerue, if he can thereto frame his ſpirit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volum.
SPEECH.LINE: He must, and will:
Prythee now ſay you will, and goe about it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Must I goe ſhew them my vnbarb’d Sconce?
Must I with my base Tongue giue to my Noble Heart
A Lye, that it must beare well? I will doo't:
Yet were there but this ſingle Plot, to loose
This Mould of Martius, they to dust ſhould grinde it,
And throw't against the Winde. Toth' Market place:
You haue put me now to ſuch a part, which neuer
I ſhall discharge toth' Life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come, wee'le prompt you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volum.
SPEECH.LINE: I prythee now ſweet Son, as thou hast ſaid
My praises made thee first a Souldier; ſo
To haue my praise for this, performe a part
Thou hast not done before.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, I must doo't:
Away my disposition, and poſſeſſe me
Some Harlots ſpirit: My throat of Warre be turn’d,
Which quier’d with my Drumme into a Pipe,
Small as an Eunuch, or the Virgin voyce
That Babies lull a-sleepe: The ſmiles of Knaues
Tent in my cheekes, and Schoole-boyes Teares take vp
The Glaſſes of my ſight: A Beggars Tongue
Make motion through my Lips, and my Arm’d knees
Who bow’d but in my Stirrop, bend like his
That hath receiu’d an Almes. I will not doo't,
Least I ſurcease to honor mine owne truth,
And by my Bodies action, teach my Minde
A mo’t inherent Baseneſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volum.
SPEECH.LINE: At thy choice then:
To begge of thee, it is my more dis-honor,
Then thou of them. Come all to ruine, let
Thy Mother rather feele thy Pride, then feare
Thy dangerous Stoutneſſe: for I mocke at death
With as bigge heart as thou. Do as thou list,
Thy Valiantneſſe was mine, thou ſuck'st it from me:
But owe thy Pride thy ſelfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray be content:
Mother, I am going to the Market place:
Chide me no more. Ile Mountebanke their Loues,
Cogge their Hearts from them, and come home belou’d
Of all the Trades in Rome. Looke, I am going:
Commend me to my Wife, Ile returne Consull,
Or neuer trust to what my Tongue can do
I'th way of Flattery further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volum
SPEECH.LINE: Do your will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: Away, the Tribunes do attend you: arm your ſelf
To anſwer mildely: for they are prepar’d
With Accusations, as I heare more ſtrong
Then are vpon you yet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: The word is, Mildely. Pray you let vs go,
Let them accuse me by inuention: I
Will anſwer in mine Honor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Menen.
SPEECH.LINE: I, but mildely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio
SPEECH.LINE: Well mildely be it then, Mildely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: In this point charge him home, that he affects
Tyrannicall power: If he euade vs there,
Inforce him with his enuy to the people,
And that the Spoile got on the Antiats
Was ne're distributed. What, will he come?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edile.
SPEECH.LINE: Hee's comming.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: How accompanied?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edile.
SPEECH.LINE: With old Menenius, and those Senators
That alwayes fauour’d him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue you a Catalogue
Of all the Voices that we haue procur’d, ſet downe by'th Pole?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edile.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue: ‘tis ready.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue you collected them by Tribes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edile.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Aſſemble presently the people hither:
And when they heare me ſay, it ſhall be ſo,
I'th’ right and ſtrength a'th’ Commons: be it either
For death, for fine, or Banishment, then let them
If I ſay Fine, cry Fine; if Death, cry Death,
Insisting on the olde prerogatiue
And power i'th Truth a'th Cause.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edile.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhall informe them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: And when ſuch time they haue begun to cry,
Let them not cease, but with a dinne confus’d
Inforce the present Execution
Of what we chance to Sentence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edi.
SPEECH.LINE: Very well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Make them be ſtrong, and ready for this hint
When we ſhall hap to giu't them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Go about it, Put him to Choller ſtraite, he hath bene vs’d Euer to conquer, and to haue his worth Of contradiction. Being once chaft, he cannot Be rein’d againe to Temperance, then he ſpeakes What's in his heart, and that is there which lookes With vs to breake his necke.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Coriolanus, Menenius, and Comi-nius, with others

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, heere he comes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: Calmely, I do beseech you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: I, as an Hostler, that fourth poorest peece
Will beare the Knaue by'th Volume:
Th’ honor’d Goddes
Keepe Rome in ſafety, and the Chaires of Iustice
Supplied with worthy men, plant loue amongs
Through our large Temples with y ſhewes of peace
And not our ſtreets with Warre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1 Sen.
SPEECH.LINE: Amen, Amen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: A Noble wish.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter the Edile with the Plebeians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Draw neere ye people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edile.
SPEECH.LINE: List to your Tribunes. Audience:
Peace I ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: First heare me ſpeake.
Both Tri.
Well, ſay: Peace hœ.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Shall I be charg’d no further then this present?
Must all determine heere?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: I do demand,
If you ſubmit you to the peoples voices,
Allow their Officers, and are content
To ſuffer lawfull Censure for ſuch faults
As ſhall be prou’d vpon you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: I am Content.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: Lo Citizens, he ſayes he is Content.
The warlike Seruice he ha's done, consider: Thinke
Vpon the wounds his body beares, which ſhew
Like Graues i'th holy Church-yard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Scratches with Briars, ſcarres to moue
Laughter onely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: Consider further:
That when he ſpeakes not like a Citizen,
You finde him like a Soldier: do not take
His rougher Actions for malicious ſounds:
But as I ſay, ſuch as become a Soldier,
Rather then enuy you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, well, no more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: What is the matter,
That being past for Consull with full voyce:
I am ſo dishonour’d, that the very houre
You take it off againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Answer to vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Say then: ‘tis true, I ought ſo

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: We charge you, that you haue contriu’d to take
From Rome all ſeason’d Office, and to winde
Your ſelfe into a power tyrannicall,
For which you are a Traitor to the people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: How? Traytor?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay temperately: your promise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: The fires i'th’ lowest hell. Fould in the people:
Call me their Traitor, thou iniurious Tribune.
Within thine eyes ſate twenty thousand deaths
In thy hands clutcht: as many Millions in
Thy lying tongue, both numbers. I would ſay
Thou lyest vnto thee, with a voice as free,
As I do pray the Gods.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Marke you this people?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: To'th’ Rocke, to'th’ Rocke with him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace:
We neede not put new matter to his charge:
What you haue ſeene him do, and heard him ſpeake:
Beating your Officers, cursing your ſelues,
Opposing Lawes with ſtroakes, and heere defying
Those whose great power must try him.
Euen this ſo criminall, and in ſuch capitall kinde
Deserues th’ extreamest death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: But ſince he hath ſeru’d well for Rome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: What do you prate of Seruice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brut.
SPEECH.LINE: I talke of that, that know it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: You?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: Is this the promise that you made your mother.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: Know, I pray you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile know no further:
Let them pronounce the ſteepe Tarpeian death,
Vagabond exile, Fleaing, pent to linger
But with a graine a day, I would not buy
Their mercie, at the price of one faire word,
Nor checke my Courage for what they can giue,
To haue't with ſaying, Good morrow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: For that he ha's
(As much as in him lies) from time to time
Enui’d against the people; ſeeking meanes
To plucke away their power: as now at last,
Giuen Hostile ſtrokes, and that not in the presence
Of dreaded Iustice, but on the Ministers
That doth distribute it. In the name a'th’ people,
And in the power of vs the Tribunes, wee
(Eu'n from this instant) banish him our Citie
In perill of precipitation
From off the Rocke Tarpeian, neuer more
To enter our Rome gates. I'th’ Peoples name,
I ſay it ſhall bee ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: It ſhall be ſo, it ſhall be ſo: let him away:
Hee's banish’d, and it ſhall be ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: Heare me my Masters, and my common friends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: He's ſentenc’d: No more hearing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: Let me ſpeake:
I haue bene Consull, and can ſhew from Rome
Her Enemies markes vpon me. I do loue
My Countries good, with a respect more tender,
More holy, and profound, then mine owne life,
My deere Wiues estimate, her wombes encrease,
And treasure of my Loynes: then if I would
Speake that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: We know your drift. Speake what?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: There's no more to be ſaid, but he is banish’d
As Enemy to the people, and his Countrey.
It ſhall bee ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: It ſhall be ſo, it ſhall be ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: You common cry of Curs, whose breath I hate,
As reeke a'th’ rotten Fennes: whose Loues I prize,
As the dead Carkaſſes of vnburied men,
That do corrupt my Ayre: I banish you,
And heere remaine with your vncertaintie.
Let euery feeble Rumor ſhake your hearts:
Your Enemies, with nodding of their Plumes
Fan you into dispaire: Haue the power ſtill
To banish your Defenders, till at length
Your ignorance (which findes not till it feeles,
Making but reseruation of your ſelues,
Still your owne Fœs) deliuer you
As mo’t abated Captiues, to ſome Nation
That wonne you without blowes, despising
For you the City. Thus I turne my backe;
There is a world elsewhere.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Exeunt Coriolanus, Cominius, with Cumalijs. They all ſhout, and throw vp their Caps

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edile.
SPEECH.LINE: The peoples Enemy is gone, is gone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: Our enemy is banish’d, he is gone: Hoo, oo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Go ſee him out at Gates, and follow him
As he hath follow’d you, with all despight
Giue him deseru’d vexation. Let a guard
Attend vs through the City.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come, lets ſee him out at gates, come:
The Gods preserue our Noble Tribunes, come.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Coriolanus, Volumnia, Virgilia, Menenius, Cominius, with the yong Nobility of Rome

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Come leaue your teares: a brief farwel: the beast
With many heads butts me away. Nay Mother,
Where is your ancient Courage? You were vs’d
To ſay, Extreamities was the trier of ſpirits,
That common chances. Common men could beare,
That when the Sea was calme, all Boats alike
Shew’d Mastership in floating. Fortunes blowes,
When mo’t ſtrooke home, being gentle wounded, craues
A Noble cunning. You were vs’d to load me
With Precepts that would make inuincible
The heart that conn’d them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Virg.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh heauens! O heauens!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, I prythee woman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vol.
SPEECH.LINE: Now the Red Pestilence ſtrike al Trades in Rome,
And Occupations perish.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: What, what, what:
I ſhall be lou’d when I am lack’d. Nay Mother,
Resume that Spirit, when you were wont to ſay,
If you had beene the Wife of Hercules,
Six of his Labours youl’d haue done, and ſau’d
Your Husband ſo much ſwet. Cominius,
Droope not, Adieu: Farewell my Wife, my Mother,
Ile do well yet. Thou old and true Menenius,
Thy teares are ſalter then a yonger mans,
And venomous to thine eyes. My (sometime) Generall,
I haue ſeene the Sterne, and thou hast oft beheld
Heart-hardning ſpectacles. Tell these ſad women,
Tis fond to waile ineuitable ſtrokes,
As ‘tis to laugh at 'em. My Mother, you wot well
My hazards ſtill haue beene your ſolace, and
Beleeu't not lightly, though I go alone
Like to a lonely Dragon, that his Fenne
Makes fear’d, and talk’d of more then ſeene: your Sonne
Will or exceed the Common, or be caught
With cautelous baits and practice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volum.
SPEECH.LINE: My first ſonne,
Whether will thou go? Take good Cominius
With thee awhile: Determine on ſome course
More then a wilde exposture, to each chance
That ſtarts i'th’ way before thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: O the Gods!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile follow thee a Moneth, deuise with thee
Where thou ſhalt rest, that thou may'st heare of vs,
And we of thee. So if the time thrust forth
A cause for thy Repeale, we ſhall not ſend
O're the vast world, to ſeeke a ſingle man,
And loose aduantage, which doth euer coole
Ith' absence of the needer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Fare ye well:
Thou hast yeares vpon thee, and thou art too full
Of the warres ſurfets, to go roue with one
That's yet vnbruis’d: bring me but out at gate.
Come my ſweet wife, my deerest Mother, and
My Friends of Noble touch: when I am forth,
Bid me farewell, and ſmile. I pray you come:
While I remaine aboue the ground, you ſhall
Heare from me ſtill, and neuer of me ought
But what is like me formerly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Menen.
SPEECH.LINE: That's worthily
As any eare can heare. Come, let's not weepe,
If I could ſhake off but one ſeuen yeeres
From these old armes and legges, by the good Gods
I'ld with thee, euery foot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio
SPEECH.LINE: Giue me thy hand, come.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter the two Tribunes, Sicinius, and Brutus, with the Edile

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Bid them all home, he's gone: & wee'l no further,
The Nobility are vexed, whom we ſee haue ſided
In his behalfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brut.
SPEECH.LINE: Now we haue ſhewne our power,
Let vs ſeeme humbler after it is done,
Then when it was a dooing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Bid them home: ſay their great enemy is gone,
And they, ſtand in their ancient ſtrength.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brut.
SPEECH.LINE: Dismiſſe them home. Here comes his Mother.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Let's not meet her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brut.
SPEECH.LINE: Why?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: They ſay ſhe's mad.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brut.
SPEECH.LINE: They haue tane note of vs: keepe on your way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volum.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh y'are well met:
Th’ hoorded plague a'th’ Gods requit your loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Menen.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace, peace, be not ſo loud.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volum.
SPEECH.LINE: If that I could for weeping, you ſhould heare,
Nay, and you ſhall heare ſome. Will you be gone?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Virg.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſhall ſtay too: I would I had the power
To ſay ſo to my Husband.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Are you mankinde?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volum.
SPEECH.LINE: I foole, is that a ſhame. Note but this Foole,
Was not a man my Father? Had'st thou Foxship
To banish him that ſtrooke more blowes for Rome
Then thou hast ſpoken words.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh bleſſed Heauens!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volum.
SPEECH.LINE: Mœ Noble blowes, then euer y wise words.
And for Romes good, Ile tell thee what: yet goe:
Nay but thou ſhalt ſtay too: I would my Sonne
Were in Arabia, and thy Tribe before him,
His good Sword in his hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: What then?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Virg.
SPEECH.LINE: When then? Hee'ld make an end of thy posterity

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volum.
SPEECH.LINE: Bastards, and all.
Good man, the Wounds that he does beare for Rome!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Menen.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come, peace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: I would he had continued to his Country
As he began, and not vnknit himselfe
The Noble knot he made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: I would he had.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volum.
SPEECH.LINE: I would he had? Twas thou incenst the rable.
Cats, that can iudge as fitly of his worth,
As I can of those Mysteries which heauen
Will not haue earth to know.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brut.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray let's go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volum.
SPEECH.LINE: Now pray ſir get you gone.
You haue done a braue deede: Ere you go, heare this:
As farre as doth the Capitoll exceede
The meanest house in Rome; ſo farre my Sonne
This Ladies Husband heere; this (do you ſee)
Whom you haue banish’d, does exceed you all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, well, wee'l leaue you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ſtay we to be baited
With one that wants her Wits.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volum.
SPEECH.LINE: Take my Prayers with you.
I would the Gods had nothing else to do,
But to confirme my Curſſes. Could I meete 'em
But once a day, it would vnclogge my heart
Of what lyes heauy too't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: You haue told them home,
And by my troth you haue cause: you'l Sup with me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volum.
SPEECH.LINE: Angers my Meate: I ſuppe vpon my ſelfe,
And ſo ſhall ſterue with Feeding: come, let's go,
Leaue this faint-puling, and lament as I do,
In Anger, Iuno-like: Come, come, come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene
SPEECH.LINE: Fie, fie, fie.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter a Roman, and a Volce.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: I know you well ſir, and you know mee: your name I thinke is Adrian.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volce.
SPEECH.LINE: It is ſo ſir, truly I haue forgot you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: I am a Roman, and my Seruices are as you are, against 'em. Know you me yet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volce.
SPEECH.LINE: Nicanor: no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: The ſame ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volce.
SPEECH.LINE: You had more Beard when I last ſaw you, but your Fauour is well appear’d by your Tongue. What's the Newes in Rome: I haue a Note from the Volcean ſtate to finde you out there. You haue well ſaued mee a dayes iourney.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: There hath beene in Rome ſtraunge Insurrecti-ons:
The people, against the Senatours, Patricians, and
Nobles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vol.
SPEECH.LINE: Hath bin; is it ended then? Our State thinks not ſo, they are in a mo’t warlike preparation, & hope to com vpon them, in the heate of their diuision

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: The maine blaze of it is past, but a ſmall thing would make it flame againe. For the Nobles receyue ſo to heart, the Banishment of that worthy Coriolanus, that they are in a ripe aptneſſe, to take al power from the peo-ple, and to plucke from them their Tribunes for euer. This lyes glowing I can tell you, and is almost mature for the violent breaking out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vol.
SPEECH.LINE: Coriolanus Banisht?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: Banish’d ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vol.
SPEECH.LINE: You will be welcome with this intelligence Ni-canor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: The day ſerues well for them now. I haue heard it ſaide, the fittest time to corrupt a mans Wife, is when ſhee's falne out with her Husband. Your Noble Tullus Auffidius will appeare well in these Warres, his great Opposer Coriolanus being now in no request of his coun-trey. _

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volce.
SPEECH.LINE: He cannot choose: I am mo’t fortunate, thus accidentally to encounter you. You haue ended my Bu-sineſſe, and I will merrily accompany you home.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhall betweene this and Supper, tell you mo’t ſtrange things from Rome: all tending to the good of their Aduersaries. Haue you an Army ready ſay you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vol.
SPEECH.LINE: A mo’t Royall one: The Centurions, and their charges distinctly billetted already in th’ entertainment, and to be on foot at an houres warning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom.
SPEECH.LINE: I am ioyfull to heare of their readineſſe, and am the man I thinke, that ſhall ſet them in present Action. So ſir, heartily well met, and mo’t glad of your Company.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volce.
SPEECH.LINE: You take my part from me ſir, I haue the mo’t cause to be glad of yours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rom
SPEECH.LINE: Well, let vs go together. Exeunt.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Coriolanus in meane Apparrell, dis-guisd, and muffled

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: A goodly City is this Antium. Citty,
‘Tis I that made thy Widdowes: Many an heyre
Of these faire Edifices fore my Warres
Haue I heard groane, and drop: Then know me not,
Least that thy Wiues with Spits, and Boyes with ſtones
In puny Battell ſlay me. Saue you ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: And you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Direct me, if it be your will, where great Auf-fidius lies: Is he in Antium?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: He is, and Feasts the Nobles of the State, at his house this night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Which is his house, beseech you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: This heere before you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio
SPEECH.LINE: Thanke you ſir, farewell. Exit Citizen Oh World, thy ſlippery turnes! Friends now fast ſworn, Whose double bosomes ſeemes to weare one heart, Whose Houres, whose Bed, whose Meale and Exercise Are ſtill together: who Twin (as 'twere) in Loue, Vnseparable, ſhall within this houre, On a diſſention of a Doit, breake out To bitterest Enmity: So fellest Fœs, Whose Paſſions, and whose Plots haue broke their ſleep To take the one the other, by ſome chance, Some tricke not worth an Egge, ſhall grow deere friends And inter-ioyne their yſſues. So with me, My Birth-place haue I, and my loues vpon This Enemie Towne: Ile enter, if he ſlay me He does faire Iustice: if he giue me way, Ile do his Country Seruice. Exit. Musicke playes. Enter a Seruingman. 1 Ser. Wine, Wine, Wine: What ſeruice is heere? I thinke our Fellowes are asleepe. Enter another Seruingman. 2 Ser Where's Cotus: my M[aster]. cals for him: Cotus. Exit

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: A goodly House:
The Feast ſmels well: but I appeare not like a Guest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1 Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: What would you haue Friend? whence are you?
Here's no place for you: pray go to the doore?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue deseru’d no better entertainment, in be-ing Coriolanus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2 Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: Whence are you ſir? Ha's the Porter his eyes in his head, that he giues entrance to ſuch Companions? Pray get you out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2 Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: Away? Get you away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Now th’art troublesome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2 Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: Are you ſo braue: Ile haue you talkt with anon
What Fellowes this?
A ſtrange one as euer I look’d on: I cannot get him out o'th house: Prythee call my Master to him.
What haue you to do here fellow? Pray you auoid the house.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Let me but ſtand, I will not hurt your Harth.
What are you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: A Gentleman.
A maru'llous poore one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: True, ſo I am.
Pray you poore Gentleman, take vp ſome other ſta-tion:
Heere's no place for you, pray you auoid: Come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Follow your Function, go, and batten on colde bits.
What you will not? Prythee tell my Maister what a ſtrange Guest he ha's heere.
And I ſhall. Exit ſecond Seruingman.
Where dwel'st thou?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Vnder the Canopy.
Vnder the Canopy?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: I.
Where's that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: I'th City of Kites and crowes.
I'th City of Kites and Crowes? What an Aſſe it is, then thou dwel'st with Dawes too?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: No, I ſerue not thy Master.
How ſir? Do you meddle with my Master?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: I, tis an honester ſeruice, then to meddle with thy Mistris: Thou prat'st, and prat'st, ſerue with thy tren-cher: Hence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Auf.
SPEECH.LINE: Where is this Fellow?
Here ſir, I’de haue beaten him like a dogge, but for disturbing the Lords within.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Auf.
SPEECH.LINE: Whence com'st thou? What wouldst y? Thy name?
Why ſpeak'st not? Speake man: What's thy name?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: If Tullus not yet thou know'st me, and ſeeing me, dost not thinke me for the man I am, neceſſitie com-mands me name my ſelfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Auf.
SPEECH.LINE: What is thy name?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: A name vnmusicall to the Volcians eares,
And harsh in ſound to thine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Auf.
SPEECH.LINE: Say, what’s thy name?
Thou hast a Grim apparance, and thy Face
Beares a Command in't: Though thy Tackles torne,
Thou ſhew'st a Noble Veſſell: What's thy name?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: Prepare thy brow to frowne: knowst y me yet?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Auf.
SPEECH.LINE: I know thee not? Thy Name:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: My name is Caius Martius, who hath done
To thee particularly, and to all the Volces
Great hurt and Mischiefe: thereto witneſſe may
My Surname Coriolanus. The painfull Seruice,
The extreme Dangers, and the droppes of Blood
Shed for my thankleſſe Country, are requitted:
But with that Surname, a good memorie
And witneſſe of the Malice and Displeasure
Which thou ſhould'st beare me, only that name remains.
The Cruelty and Enuy of the people,
Permitted by our dastard Nobles, who
Haue all forsooke me, hath deuour’d the rest:
And ſuffer’d me by th’ voyce of Slaues to be
Hoop’d out of Rome. Now this extremity,
Hath brought me to thy Harth, not out of Hope
(Mistake me not) to ſaue my life: for if
I had fear’d death, of all the Men i'th’ World
I would haue voided thee. But in meere ſpight
To be full quit of those my Banishers,
Stand I before thee heere: Then if thou hast
A heart of wreake in thee, that wilt reuenge
Thine owne particular wrongs, and ſtop those maimes
Of ſhame ſeene through thy Country, ſpeed thee ſtraight
And make my misery ſerue thy turne: So vse it,
That my reuengefull Seruices may proue
As Benefits to thee. For I will fight
Against my Cankred Countrey, with the Spleene
Of all the vnder Fiends. But if ſo be,
Thou dar'st not this, and that to proue more Fortunes
Th'art tyr’d, then in a word, I also am
Longer to liue mo’t wearie: and present
My throat to thee, and to thy Ancient Malice:
Which not to cut, would ſhew thee but a Foole,
Since I haue euer followed thee with hate,
Drawne Tunnes of Blood out of thy Countries brest,
And cannot liue but to thy ſhame, vnleſſe
It be to do thee ſeruice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Auf.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh Martius, Martius;
Each word thou hast ſpoke, hath weeded from my heart
A roote of Ancient Enuy. If Iupiter
Should from yond clowd ſpeake diuine things,
And ſay ‘tis true; I’de not beleeue them more
Then thee all-Noble Martius. Let me twine
Mine armes about that body, where against
My grained Ash an hundred times hath broke,
And ſcarr’d the Moone with ſplinters: heere I cleep
The Anuile of my Sword, and do contest
As hotly, and as Nobly with thy Loue,
As euer in Ambitious ſtrength, I did
Contend against thy Valour. Know thou first,
I lou’d the Maid I married: neuer man
Sigh’d truer breath. But that I ſee thee heere
Thou Noble thing, more dances my rapt heart,
Then when I first my wedded Mistris ſaw
Bestride my Threshold. Why, thou Mars I tell thee,
We haue a Power on foote: and I had purpose
Once more to hew thy Target from thy Brawne,
Or loose mine Arme for't: Thou hast beate mee out
Twelue ſeuerall times, and I haue nightly ſince
Dreamt of encounters 'twixt thy ſelfe and me:
We haue beene downe together in my ſleepe,
Vnbuckling Helmes, fisting each others Throat,
And wak’d halfe dead with nothing. Worthy Martius,
Had we no other quarrell else to Rome, but that
Thou art thence Banish’d, we would muster all
From twelue, to ſeuentie: and powring Warre
Into the bowels of vngratefull Rome,
Like a bold Flood o’re-beate. Oh come, go in,
And take our friendly Senators by'th’ hands
Who now are heere, taking their leaues of mee,
Who am prepar’d against your Territories,
Though not for Rome it ſelfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: You bleſſe me Gods.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Auf.
SPEECH.LINE: Therefore mo’t absolute Sir, if thou wilt haue
The leading of thine owne Reuenges, take
Th’ one halfe of my Commiſſion, and ſet downe
As best thou art experienc’d, ſince thou know'st
Thy Countries ſtrength and weakneſſe, thine own waies
Whether to knocke against the Gates of Rome,
Or rudely visit them in parts remote,
To fright them, ere destroy. But come in,
Let me commend thee first, to those that ſhall
Say yea to thy desires. A thousand welcomes,
And more a Friend, then ere an Enemie,
Yet Martius that was much. Your hand: mo’t welcome.
Heere's a ſtrange alteration?
By my hand, I had thoght to haue ſtroken him with a Cudgell, and yet my minde gaue me, his cloathes made a false report of him.
What an Arme he has, he turn’d me about with his finger and his thumbe, as one would ſet vp a Top.
Nay, I knew by his face that there was ſome-thing in him. He had ſir, a kinde of face me thought, I cannot tell how to tearme it.
He had ſo, looking as it were, would I were hang’d but I thought there was more in him, then I could think.
So did I, Ile be ſworne: He is ſimply the rarest man i'th’ world.
I thinke he is: but a greater ſoldier then he,
You wot one.
Who my Master?
Nay, it's no matter for that.
Worth ſix on him.
Nay not ſo neither: but I take him to be the greater
Souldiour.
Faith looke you, one cannot tell how to ſay that: for the Defence of a Towne, our Generall is excellent.
I, and for an aſſault too.
Oh Slaues, I can tell you Newes, News you Rascals

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Both.
SPEECH.LINE: What, what, what? Let's partake.
I would not be a Roman of all Nations; I had as liue be a condemn’d man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Both.
SPEECH.LINE: Wherefore? Wherefore?
Why here's he that was wont to thwacke our Ge-nerall,
Caius Martius.
Why do you ſay, thwacke our Generall?
I do not ſay thwacke our Generall, but he was al-wayes good enough for him
Come we are fellowes and friends: he was euer too hard for him, I haue heard him ſay ſo himselfe.
He was too hard for him directly, to ſay the Troth on't before Corioles, he ſcotcht him, and notcht him like a Carbinado.
And hee had bin Cannibally giuen, hee might haue boyld and eaten him too.
But more of thy Newes.

Why he is ſo made on heere within, as if hee were Son and Heire to Mars, ſet at vpper end o'th’ Table: No question askt him by any of the Senators, but they ſtand bald before him. Our Generall himselfe makes a Mistris of him, Sanctifies himselfe with's hand, and turnes vp the white o'th’ eye to his Discourse. But the bottome of the Newes is, our Generall is cut i'th’ middle, & but one halfe of what he was yesterday. For the other ha's halfe, by the intreaty and graunt of the whole Table. Hee'l go he ſayes, and ſole the Porter of Rome Gates by th’ eares. He will mowe all downe before him, and leaue his paſſage poul’d.
And he's as like to do't, as any man I can imagine.

Doo't? he will doo't: for look you ſir, he has as ma-ny Friends as Enemies: which Friends ſir as it were, durst not (looke you ſir) ſhew themselues (as we terme it) his Friends, whilest he's in Directitude.
Directitude? What's that?
But when they ſhall ſee ſir, his Crest vp againe, and the man in blood, they will out of their Burroughes (like Conies after Raine) and reuell all with him.
But when goes this forward:
To morrow, to day, presently, you ſhall haue the Drum ſtrooke vp this afternoone: ‘Tis as it were a parcel of their Feast, and to be executed ere they wipe their lips.
Why then wee ſhall haue a ſtirring World againe: This peace is nothing, but to rust Iron, encrease Taylors, and breed Ballad-makers.

Let me haue Warre ſay I, it exceeds peace as farre as day do's night: It's ſprightly walking, audible, and full of Vent. Peace, is a very Apoplexy, Lethargie, mull’d, deafe, ſleepe, insensible, a getter of more bastard Chil-dren, then warres a destroyer of men.
‘Tis ſo, and as warres in ſome ſort may be ſaide to be a Rauisher, ſo it cannot be denied, but peace is a great maker of Cuckolds.
I, and it makes men hate one another.
Reason, because they then leſſe neede one another: The Warres for my money. I hope to ſee Romanes as cheape as Volcians. They are rising, they are rising.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Both
SPEECH.LINE: In, in, in, in.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter the two Tribunes, Sicinius, and Brutus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: We heare not of him, neither need we fear him,
His remedies are tame, the present peace,
And quietneſſe of the people, which before
Were in wilde hurry. Heere do we make his Friends
Blush, that the world goes well: who rather had,
Though they themselues did ſuffer by't, behold
Diſſentious numbers pestring ſtreets, then ſee
Our Tradesmen ſinging in their ſhops, and going
About their Functions friendly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: We ſtood too't in good time. Is this Menenius?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis he, ‘tis he: O he is grown mo’t kind of late:
Haile Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: Haile to you both.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Your Coriolanus is not much mist, but with his Friends: the Commonwealth doth ſtand, and ſo would do, were he more angry at it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: All's well, and might haue bene much better, if he could haue temporiz’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Where is he, heare you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay I heare nothing:
His Mother and his wife, heare nothing from him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: The Gods preserue you both.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Gooden our Neighbours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Gooden to you all, gooden to you all.
Our ſelues, our wiues, and children, on our knees,
Are bound to pray for you both.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Liue, and thriue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell kinde Neighbours:
We wisht Coriolanus had lou’d you as we did.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: Now the Gods keepe you.
Both Tri
Farewell, farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: This is a happier and more comely time,
Then when these Fellowes ran about the ſtreets,
Crying Confusion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Caius Martius was
A worthy Officer i'th’ Warre, but Insolent,
O'recome with Pride, Ambitious, past all thinking
Selfe-louing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: And affecting one ſole Throne, without aſſista[n]ce

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke not ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: We ſhould by this, to all our Lamention,
If he had gone forth Consull, found it ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: The Gods haue well preuented it, and Rome
Sits ſafe and ſtill, without him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aedile.
SPEECH.LINE: Worthy Tribunes,
There is a Slaue whom we haue put in prison,
Reports the Volces with two ſeuerall Powers
Are entred in the Roman Territories,
And with the deepest malice of the Warre,
Destroy, what lies before' em.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis Auffidius,
Who hearing of our Martius Banishment,
Thrusts forth his hornes againe into the world
Which were In-shell’d, when Martius ſtood for Rome,
And durst not once peepe out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, what talke you of Martius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Go ſee this Rumorer whipt, it cannot be,
The Volces dare breake with vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: Cannot be?
We haue Record, that very well it can,
And three examples of the like, hath beene
Within my Age. But reason with the fellow
Before you punish him, where he heard this,
Least you ſhall chance to whip your Information,
And beate the Meſſenger, who bids beware
Of what is to be dreaded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Tell not me: I know this cannot be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Not poſſible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: The Nobles in great earnestneſſe are going
All to the Senate-house: ſome newes is comming
That turnes their Countenances.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis this Slaue:
Go whip him fore the peoples eyes: His raising,
Nothing but his report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes worthy Sir,
The Slaues report is ſeconded, and more
More fearfull is deliuer’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: What more fearefull?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: It is ſpoke freely out of many mouths,
How probable I do not know, that Martius
Ioyn’d with Auffidius, leads a power 'gainst Rome,
And vowes Reuenge as ſpacious, as betweene
The yong'st and oldest thing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: This is mo’t likely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Rais’d onely, that the weaker ſort may wish
Good Martius home againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: The very tricke on't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: This is vnlikely,
He, and Auffidius can no more attone
Then violent'st Contrariety.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: You are ſent for to the Senate:
A fearefull Army, led by Caius Martius,
Aſſociated with Auffidius, Rages
Vpon our Territories, and haue already
O're-borne their way, consum’d with fire, and tooke
What lay before them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh you haue made good worke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: What newes? What newes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: You haue holp to rauish your owne daughters, &
To melt the Citty Leades vpon your pates,
To ſee your Wiues dishonour’d to your Noses.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: What's the newes? What's the newes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: Your Temples burned in their Ciment, and
Your Franchises, whereon you ſtood, confin’d
Into an Augors boare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray now, your Newes:
You haue made faire worke I feare me: pray your newes,
If Martius ſhould be ioyn’d with Volceans.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: If? He is their God, he leads them like a thing
Made by ſome other Deity then Nature,
That ſhapes man Better: and they follow him
Against vs Brats, with no leſſe Confidence,
Then Boyes pursuing Summer Butter-flies,
Or Butchers killing Flyes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: You haue made good worke,
You and your Apron men: you, that ſtood ſo much
Vpon the voyce of occupation, and
The breath of Garlicke-eaters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: Hee'l ſhake your Rome about your eares.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: As Hercules did ſhake downe Mellow Fruite:
You haue made faire worke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brut.
SPEECH.LINE: But is this true ſir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: I, and you'l looke pale
Before you finde it other. All the Regions
Do ſmilingly Reuolt, and who resists
Are mock’d for valiant Ignorance,
And perish constant Fooles: who is't can blame him?
Your Enemies and his, finde ſomething in him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: We are all vndone, vnleſſe
The Noble man haue mercy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: Who ſhall aske it?
The Tribunes cannot doo't for ſhame; the people
Deserue ſuch pitty of him, as the Wolfe
Doe's of the Shepheards: For his best Friends, if they
Should ſay be good to Rome, they charg’d him, euen
As those ſhould do that had deseru’d his hate,
And therein ſhew’d like Enemies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Me.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis true, if he were putting to my house, the brand
That ſhould consume it, I haue not the face
To ſay, beseech you cease. You haue made faire hands,
You and your Crafts, you haue crafted faire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: You haue brought
A Trembling vpon Rome, ſuch as was neuer
S' incapeable of helpe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tri.
SPEECH.LINE: Say not, we brought it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: How? Was't we? We lou’d him,
But like Beasts, and Cowardly Nobles,
Gaue way vnto your Clusters, who did hoote
Him out o'th’ Citty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: But I feare
They'l roare him in againe. Tullus Affidius,
The ſecond name of men, obeyes his points
As if he were his Officer: Desperation,
Is all the Policy, Strength, and Defence
That Rome can make against them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere come the Clusters.
And is Auffidius with him? You are they
That made the Ayre vnwholsome, when you cast
Your ſtinking, greasie Caps, in hooting
At Coriolanus Exile. Now he's comming,
And not a haire vpon a Souldiers head
Which will not proue a whip: As many Coxcombes
As you threw Caps vp, will he tumble downe,
And pay you for your voyces. ‘Tis no matter,
If he could burne vs all into one coale,
We haue deseru’d it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SPEECH.LINE: Faith, we heare fearfull Newes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1 Cit.
SPEECH.LINE: For mine owne part,
When I ſaid banish him, I ſaid 'twas pitty.
And ſo did I.
And ſo did I: and to ſay the truth, ſo did very ma-ny of vs, that we did we did for the best, and though wee willingly consented to his Banishment, yet it was against our will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: Y'are goodly things, you Voyces.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: You haue made good worke
You and your cry. Shal's to the Capitoll?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com
SPEECH.LINE: Oh I, what else?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Go Masters get you home, be not dismaid, These are a Side, that would be glad to haue This true, which they ſo ſeeme to feare. Go home, And ſhew no ſigne of Feare. 1 Cit. The Gods bee good to vs: Come Masters let's home, I euer ſaid we were i'th wrong, when we banish’d him. 2 Cit So did we all. But come, let's home.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: I do not like this Newes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Nor I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Let's to the Capitoll: would halfe my wealth
Would buy this for a lye.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin
SPEECH.LINE: Pray let's go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Auf.
SPEECH.LINE: Do they ſtill flye to'th’ Roman?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lieu.
SPEECH.LINE: I do not know what Witchcraft's in him: but
Your Soldiers vse him as the Grace 'fore meate,
Their talke at Table, and their Thankes at end,
And you are darkned in this action Sir,
Euen by your owne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Auf.
SPEECH.LINE: I cannot helpe it now,
Vnleſſe by vsing meanes I lame the foote
Of our designe. He beares himselfe more proudlier,
Euen to my person, then I thought he would
When first I did embrace him. Yet his Nature
In that’s no Changeling, and I must excuse
What cannot be amended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lieu.
SPEECH.LINE: Yet I wish Sir,
(I meane for your particular) you had not
Ioyn’d in Commiſſion with him: but either haue borne
The action of your ſelfe, or else to him, had left it ſoly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Auf.
SPEECH.LINE: I vnderstand thee well, and be thou ſure
When he ſhall come to his account, he knowes not
What I can vrge against him, although it ſeemes
And ſo he thinkes, and is no leſſe apparant
To th’ vulgar eye, that he beares all things fairely:
And ſhewes good Husbandry for the Volcian State,
Fights Dragon-like, and does atcheeue as ſoone
As draw his Sword: yet he hath left vndone
That which ſhall breake his necke, or hazard mine,
When ere we come to our account.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lieu.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I beseech you, think you he'l carry Rome?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Auf.
SPEECH.LINE: All places yeelds to him ere he ſits downe,
And the Nobility of Rome are his:
The Senators and Patricians loue him too:
The Tribunes are no Soldiers: and their people
Will be as rash in the repeale, as hasty
To expell him thence. I thinke hee'l be to Rome
As is the Aspray to the Fish, who takes it
By Soueraignty of Nature. First, he was
A Noble ſeruant to them, but he could not
Carry his Honors eeuen: whether 'twas Pride
Which out of dayly Fortune euer taints
The happy man; whether detect of iudgement,
To faile in the disposing of those chances
Which he was Lord of: or whether Nature,
Not to be other then one thing, not moouing
From th’ Caske to th’ Cushion: but commanding peace
Euen with the ſame austerity and garbe,
As he controll’d the warre. But one of these
(As he hath ſpices of them all) not all,
For I dare ſo farre free him, made him fear’d,
So hated, and ſo banish’d: but he ha's a Merit
To choake it in the vtt'rance: So our Vertue,
Lie in th’ interpretation of the time,
And power vnto it ſelfe mo’t commendable,
Hath not a Tombe ſo euident as a Chaire
T' extoll what it hath done.
One fire driues out one fire; one Naile, one Naile;
Rights by rights fouler, ſtrengths by ſtrengths do faile.
Come let's away: when Caius Rome is thine,
Thou art poor'st of all; then ſhortly art thou mine.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Menenius, Cominius, Sicinius, Brutus, the two Tribunes, with others

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Menen.
SPEECH.LINE: No, ile not go: you heare what he hath ſaid
Which was ſometime his Generall: who loued him
In a mo’t deere particular. He call’d me Father:
But what o'that? Go you that banish’d him
A Mile before his Tent, fall downe, and knee
The way into his mercy: Nay, if he coy’d
To heare Cominius ſpeake, Ile keepe at home.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: He would not ſeeme to know me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Menen.
SPEECH.LINE: Do you heare?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: Yet one time he did call me by my name:
I vrg’d our old acquaintance, and the drops
That we haue bled together. Coriolanus
He would not anſwer too: Forbad all Names,
He was a kinde of Nothing, Titleleſſe,
Till he had forg’d himselfe a name a'th’ fire
Of burning Rome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Menen.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ſo: you haue made good worke:
A paire of Tribunes, that haue wrack’d for Rome,
To make Coales cheape: A Noble memory.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: I minded him, how Royall 'twas to pardon
When it was leſſe expected. He replyed
It was a bare petition of a State
To one whom they had punish’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Menen.
SPEECH.LINE: Very well, could he ſay leſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: I offered to awaken his regard
For's priuate Friends. His anſwer to me was
He could not ſtay to picke them, in a pile
Of noysome musty Chaffe. He ſaid, 'twas folly
For one poore graine or two, to leaue vnburnt
And ſtill to nose th’ offence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Menen.
SPEECH.LINE: For one poore graine or two?
I am one of those: his Mother, Wife, his Childe,
And this braue Fellow too: we are the Graines,
You are the musty Chaffe, and you are ſmelt
Aboue the Moone. We must be burnt for you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, pray be patient: If you refuse your ayde
In this ſo neuer-needed helpe, yet do not
Vpbraid's with our distreſſe. But ſure if you
Would be your Countries Pleader, your good tongue
More then the instant Armie we can make
Might ſtop our Countryman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: No: Ile not meddle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray you go to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſhould I do?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Onely make triall what your Loue can do,
For Rome, towards Martius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, and ſay that Martius returne mee,
As Cominius is return’d, vnheard: what then?
But as a discontented Friend, greefe-shot
With his vnkindneſſe. Say't be ſo?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Yet your good will
Must haue that thankes from Rome, after the measure
As you intended well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile vndertak't:
I thinke hee'l heare me. Yet to bite his lip,
And humme at good Cominius, much vnhearts mee.
He was not taken well, he had not din’d,
The Veines vnfill’d, our blood is cold, and then
We powt vpon the Morning, are vnapt
To giue or to forgiue; but when we haue ſtufft
These Pipes, and these Conueyances of our blood
With Wine and Feeding, we haue ſuppler Soules
Then in our Priest-like Fasts: therefore Ile watch him
Till he be dieted to my request,
And then Ile ſet vpon him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: You know the very rode into his kindneſſe,
And cannot lose your way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: Good faith Ile proue him,
Speed how it will. I ſhall ere long, haue knowledge
Of my ſucceſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: Hee'l neuer heare him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sicin.
SPEECH.LINE: Not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Com.
SPEECH.LINE: I tell you, he doe's ſit in Gold, his eye
Red as 'twould burne Rome: and his Iniury
The Gaoler to his pitty. I kneel’d before him,
'Twas very faintly he ſaid Rise: dismist me
Thus with his ſpeechleſſe hand. What he would do
He ſent in writing after me: what he would not,
Bound with an Oath to yeeld to his conditions:
So that all hope is vaine, vnleſſe his Noble Mother,
And his Wife, who (as I heare) meane to ſolicite him
For mercy to his Countrey: therefore let's hence,
And with our faire intreaties hast them on.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Menenius to the Watch or Guard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Wat.
SPEECH.LINE: Stay: whence are you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Wat.
SPEECH.LINE: Stand, and go backe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Me.
SPEECH.LINE: You guard like men, ‘tis well. But by your leaue,
I am an Officer of State, & come to ſpeak with Coriolanus
From whence?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: From Rome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: I
SPEECH.LINE: You may not paſſe, you must returne: our Generall will no more heare from thence.
You'l ſee your Rome embrac’d with fire, before
You'l ſpeake with Coriolanus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: Good my Friends,
If you haue heard your Generall talke of Rome,
And of his Friends there, it is Lots to Blankes,
My name hath touch't your eares: it is Menenius.
Be it ſo, go back: the vertue of your name,
Is not heere paſſable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: I tell thee Fellow,
Thy Generall is my Louer: I haue beene
The booke of his good Acts, whence men haue read
His Fame vnparalell’d, happely amplified:
For I haue euer verified my Friends,
(Of whom hee's cheefe) with all the ſize that verity
Would without lapsing ſuffer: Nay, ſometimes,
Like to a Bowle vpon a ſubtle ground
I haue tumbled past the throw: and in his praise
Haue (almost) ſtampt the Leasing. Therefore Fellow,
I must haue leaue to paſſe.

Faith Sir, if you had told as many lies in his behalfe, as you haue vttered words in your owne, you ſhould not paſſe heere: no, though it were as vertuous to lye, as to liue chastly. Therefore go backe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Men.
SPEECH.LINE: Prythee fellow, remember my name is Menenius, alwayes factionary on the party of your Generall.
Howsœuer you haue bin his Lier, as you ſay you haue, I am one that telling true vnder him, must ſay you cannot paſſe. Therefore go backe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha's he din’d can'st thou tell? For I would not ſpeake with him, till after dinner.
You are a Roman, are you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: I am as thy Generall is.

Then you ſhould hate Rome, as he do's. Can you, when you haue pusht out your gates, the very Defender of them, and in a violent popular ignorance, giuen your enemy your ſhield, thinke to front his reuenges with the easie groanes of old women, the Virginall Palms of your daughters, or with the palsied interceſſion of ſuch a de-cay’d Dotant as you ſeeme to be? Can you think to blow out the intended fire, your City is ready to flame in, with ſuch weake breath as this? No, you are deceiu’d, therfore backe to Rome, and prepare for your execution: you are condemn’d, our Generall has ſworne you out of repreeue and pardon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: Sirra, if thy Captaine knew I were heere,
He would vse me with estimation.
Come, my Captaine knowes you not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: I meane thy Generall.
My Generall cares not for you. Back I ſay, go: least I let forth your halfe pinte of blood. Backe, that’s the vt-mo’t of your hauing, backe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay but Fellow, Fellow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corio.
SPEECH.LINE: What's the matter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mene.
